reviewText:
Early Access Review

This may seem as a joke coming from me but this game is... well it's....it is nearly perfect!

That first line was just for someone who was too lazy to actually read my review.

I will now get into my reasoning by using (of course) the Pros and Cons method.

PROS

-Great Combat System. Reminded me of Legend of Zelda.
-Great graphic/art style. Voxel based. Kind of like Minecraft but far better.
-Animations...enough said.
-Enemies
-Crafting system (Extremely Easy, perfect for streaming or for someone who just wants to chill)
So many more pros but I really have to get back to the game.

Now the game sounds nearly perfect right now, right? Well, everything has it's flaws.

CONS

-Cannot change resolution settings. In the game you can choose your resolution (1920x1080) but there is also a resolution option that is kind of like what you would find in Battlefield 4 or Battlefront 2015. I am unalbe to put the resolution scale to High" or the highest setting that they have available.

Here is a link for what you see when trying to change the RESOLUTION settings http://prntscr.com/acvz9r

-Few customization options. Those three words say it all. If you were looking for a game to customize your perfect hero then this game is not for you (For now). I have been informed that there is an update coming soon that will contain MORE customization options which is good news.


Overall this game is almost perfect. It makes me feel like a little child again when I was reading my fiction books about heroes battling monsters and other evil creatures. The artstyle reminds me of a Disney or Pixar animation. And the gameplay/combat is beautiful.

For now
date: I give the game a 8/10.\nIt is not a 9 or 10 because of the lack of customization
recommended:
and the inability to improve my graphical settings.

P.S
THIS IS FOR THE DEVOLOPERS IF THEY DO EVER READ MY REVIEW.

Please add a workshop for this game. The Steam community is filled with creative minds that need to be noticed. It will not only save you guys time on creating content
hoursPlayed: but it will allow us to create what we want.\n\nAlso
voteText:
do not make this game Free to Play. I love the price it is now. 15 dollars is a perfect price. Do not add any Downloadable Content or anything along those lines. THE GAME IS NEARLY PERFECT right now. Please do not screw up this game.



Thank you to anyone who has took the time to read this review and hopefully I have influenced you to Buy and/or add this game to your wishlist. The developers deserve it.

__________________________UPDATE_________________________________

They have fixed the resolution issues that I have stated earlier.

Also

votesHelpful: or even ignoring it and saving your money and buying  a different product. I say this because I got messaged a lot of people calling me a "Sellout" and a "Paid Reviewer". Just putting this out there."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is my first review of any game on Steam. Though, I have played many, many games in my lifetime. So, Here is my day 1 review - First 7 hour block of Portal Knights.

The basics
Three classes, Ive only tried the Mage/Wizard class so far. So, I cant speak of the other classes. However, Ive died a few times. Mistakes happen. It takes a minute or two just to get used to the combat camera. Once you get over that little hump the game plays really well. Day and Night cycles are nice. The sun looks great rising. Very animated and pretty.

Character creation is alright, limited but the game is new and under development so No worries there. Monsters are of a low IQ, But fighting 8 or so at a time is still tricky.Some hit pretty hard too. A few trickyones early on.
The game itself concerning the quests and exploration are really nice. Basic tutorial that gives you an idea of how it works. Quick and simple. I liked it.

The islands start really small so far, but they clearly grow larger and larger every island you jump to. Different climates and resources on certain places, very nice touch. Its not a linear path either.You can find advanced materials long before you can use them if you explore. There are hidden caches of exp and useful blocks as well, but they require some cunning to find. I truly appreciate that in this game.

The dungeons you find make you explore, the lighting and setups are very awesome. Great scenery you can borrow from them too. Fought the first boss, not too difficult but you will appreciate the combat system so much more when you fight the boss.

I see some of the other reviews dog on the crafting system. Its perfect. Gamers are extremely lazy these days and I truly appreciate the way this crafting system is. Its not too hard (Think EverQuest 1999) and its not too easy (Minecraft/Terarria). Ive come across some recipies and those are awesome too. Looking forward to finding more.

Basically, The game gets a solid 8/10

The only cons I have are as follows:

Splitting stacks. Cant do it yet.
Rebinding Keys. Cant do it yet.
Graphics adjustments. Nothing to adjust. (NOTE: Its 2016. This game isnt groundbreaking graphically. May not be needed)

I am looking forward to getting further in this game and updating my review. for now its solid. Esp for 12 bucks.

-Trounce
21 Years of gaming experience and counting.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

* A Beta Key was provided by the developer *
I will try to update the review when as I continue to play through the game

Portal Knights
Portal Knights is a cute and interesting RPG sandbox game with good execution and potential for its future. I will add a TL;DR at the end.

Gameplay
Portal Knights has an interesting and good mix and RPG, exploration, and sandbox elements within its gameplay. For me it felt as if the controls were a bit odd especially in combat, especially since you are unable to jump while in combat mode. Its controls definitely feel odd at first and first person I feel is only useful really useful for building as combat in that view can be tedious. The different recipes that can be created and the idea of upgradable workstations is great. The inventory/ backpack however feels a bit incomplete as some items do not automatically stack in it when you find more of them. You also are forced to click, hold, then drag items from your inventory and are also unable to quickly move them like you can in other sandbox games.
There is no pause option in single player/offline mode which is a tad of an annoyance if you quickly have to go do something and then you die since there is no pause. There are three classes to currently choose from and from what I see there are no specializations in weaponry or armour for any class as you can just equip the other classes armour and are able to craft it. It’s good to make classes stand out to really make them specialize and have special items.
From what I have seen the single player gameplay consists of going from island to island advancing through portals and eventually fighting bosses and being able to settle on of the islands. The first island or the tutorial island is interesting in how it gives objectives and little quests for you to do, but that is not seen in other islands. Perhaps even a kill X amount of creatures quest would be fun if you are allowed to manage your active quests/objectives.
Another cool feature is that the universes where the islands are contained and characters are compatible with each other, meaning that you can start your high level character in a new universe or start your new character in your old universe. So far the gameplay is enjoyable and refreshing and the multiple islands is something of interest and uniqueness to associate with Portal Knights along with its RPG and adventure elements.

Graphics/Sounds
The graphics in this game are cute, just really cute. It helps to add to a more laid back and relaxing experience but it’s also beautiful when you look upon the land or your own creations. The art has been done well and the music fits with an adventurous spirit.

Pros/Cons
Pros

+ 44 islands to play through
+ Good mix of RPG and Sandbox elements
+ Graphics are cute and helps to give a relaxing nature
+ Easy to pick up and play
+ 4-person multiplayer
+ 5 chracter slots and 3 universes slots (saves/world progress)

Cons
**Note since this is an Early Access title Cons and other parts of the review as well are viable to change as the game continues to develop**

- No real class specializations
- Quests are gone after tutorial island
- No real challenge (From what seen so far, just really easy to go to next islands)
- Combat is odd and removes jump ability
- Some items do not auto stack when you already have the item in your inventory creating two stacks of the same item and forced to click, hold, and drag items to move them
- No quick move from inventory to hand or chest

Suggestions
Here are some suggestions I feel would improve the game

- Quests on individual islands not just the first
- Ability to pause in single play/offline mode
- Ability to keep jump when in combat
- Class specialized clothing and weaponry (Only one class can craft/use)
- Pets
- New class Necromancer (Ability to harvest enemy souls and craft specialized weaponry which will allow summoning of one undead or the ability to set an automatic undead guard for a certain area like the house. Can be added as a specialization of the current mage class available after a certain level to unlock more specialized gear and abilities.)
- Quick move (such as Shift+Click) to move items more efficiently from hand to inventory or to a chest
- Adjustable keybindings

Final Thoughts
Portal Knights is fun and easy to get into, but like any game in early access it has its share of annoyances. I was able to enjoy it so far in my playtime and I hope to beat every single island. I was able to enjoy my time and relax within Portal Knights and I would definitely say it would be a great title to play with friends. The islands however are a thing of taste in my opinion as some people like open world exploration and being limited to islands which you have to teleport to and from is odd. It took me a bit to get used to it, but it’s also a charming feature that allows you to simply go somewhere brand new every time to kill, mine, or build. Overall I enjoyed Portal Knights except for some snippets here and there and I say that the developers have a really good chance to make this a great game.

TL;DR
Portal Knights is an adventurous sandbox RPG title with interesting gameplay. It consists of individual islands you can teleport to rather than a huge open world (from what seen so far). So far it has good gameplay and cute graphics. Overall I would say it’s a fun casual game which can be easily picked up and played solo or with friend. Feel free to check the updates to see what has been added since the time of this review and if it includes your personal tastes.

If you liked this review or want to see more recommended games, be sure to follow our curator group: Follow Original Curator Group

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you like Terraria and/or Minecraft, you will most likely love this game. I don't have a lot of time invested, but so far I really like it.

HOW THE GAME WORKS:
1. You can choose from 3 different classes. Essentially a knight, archer and mage. You gain abilities, weapons and armor sets as you lvl up and progress through each world level.
2. There are 44 worlds to progress through. each have their own theme, enemies and resources. (There are also boss worlds.)
3. The idea is to explore an area, mine its resources then find and repair the portal to the next realm (Sometimes more than one portal.)
4.You can build homes, various workstations, tools, weapons, armor, spells and potions.

The only bad thing I can say, (And this is my opinion.) is that each realm is very small. It takes 15-20min to explore each one. That being said, there are 44 realms and you have to go back to previous realms for specific resources at times, so you get decent use out of most realms. And to be honest it is kind of exciting trying to hurry and get to the next area, because you have no idea what it is!

Also take into account this game is in testing. I personally think this game has a lot of potential.

PROS:
Nice visuals.
Good progression system.
Engaging gameplay.
Really fun co-op play.

CONS:
Some bugs and crashes. (To be expected.)
Small areas.

I like this game a lot and think its worth $15. Try it out!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First off, let me say this is an absolutely stunning game with so much entertainment value. The price is absolutely worth it. I'm currently trying to encourage all my friends to get this. This game is great thus far. However, there is much room for improvement at the same time. I think with the right development this game could contest minecraft and terraria.

SUGGESTIONS:

Classes and Perks:
I'm a huge fan of games where you can play with your friends and everyone has a specific role. As it stands right now, there is much variety for classes yet. The three basic classes are a good foundation, but for this game to truly take advantage of players having roles, you should add subclasses to each of the classes.
ie
Mage:
-Battle Mage
-Support Mage

Ranger:
-Sniper
-Infantry

Warrior:
-Brute
-Assassin

Those are just a handful that i could think of, but i'm sure you guys could think up more. And their should be crafting that caters to each of the sub classes. Which leads me to my next suggestion.

Looting/Crafting:
The crafting system itself is near perfect. I LOVE how you have to upgrade your stations in order to achieve the ability to craft better gear. There should however be a lot more to choose from for every level. (also having a crafting level would be a fun addition) Not only should their be more variety withen the crafting, there should be more variety with random npc drops. I personally would find more pleasure in traveling to different biomes to grind if there was a chance of a particular monster having a 3% chance to drop a certain weapon, or armor, or item that in turn could be crafted into a very rare item. Bosses and uncommon monsters should naturally drop better loot. I gain so much more incentive to put hours into a game when i can finally get an item that none of my friends have. and there should be 100's of legendary items like that. Games like these are best when you can show off. The crafting for the most part is okay, but i think a complete overhaul of the loot/drop system is in order. ( i think a lot of inspiration should be drawn from terraria for this specific area of the game.

Stealth/NPC pathing:
First off, a stealth system would breath more life into the world. Sneaking through dungeons, Hiding from enemies while recovering health. Right now there is zero stealth and approaching mobs feels so direct and boring. Being able to sneak up for additional damage would be amazing, and could allow for you to add classes such as the assassin and sniper.


Companions/Mounts:
Considering the maps are pretty easy to get around on foot, the idea of having a mount is a merely for entertainment over functionality one. Unless there were flying mounts that could fly to floating islands. And Companions are an excellent addition to ANY game. Perhaps make companions or mounts a extremely rare drop.

Random Events:
Every biome should be subject to several rare random events. The thought of a random mini boss or waves of monsters breaking into your base would add a little spice to staying in one place for a while.

Ethetics/Materials:
Add way more furniture and a variety of color in wood and stone blocks.
Water blocks... that should be absolutely mandatory in any game like this. Even add an oasis to desert maps. The main reason i want water blocks is for ethetics at my base. I'd like the option to build a classy fountain in my town square. Furthermore, it could be used to make the farming process a bit more complex. Also, in the current game farming isn't that useful. I think adding a hunger bar would make so much since for farming. i mean you can't really have one without the other. It would also add more challenge which this game desperatly needs.

Difficulty:
I appreciate this game for what it is, but it's incredibly easy. I would love to see this game include a revival system for downed allies. Currently there are just no repurcussions to dying other than losing a little health which is so easy to get back. Or at the minimum a respawn timer. This entire game is just low risk high reward. I need a deterant to jumping off a high cliff to reach an edge in a canyon. I should think twice about most my decisions.Perhaps losing a little experience upon death would be a good system as well. Also, level zones should be more relevant.

Mage spell revamp:
This is my most passionate area of the game that i'd like to see improvement in. As it currently is spells have A LOT of power, but they all cooldown at once. What i desperately suggest is, nerf all the spells and make them cooldown individually, so you can chain spells together. I should be able to buff myself then immediately use an lightning attack. And what would balance this change would be the mana consumption. The mage class just doesn't feel like it utilizes the spells enough.

And............... An in game chat system. I don't believe i have to explain why a multiplayer game needs this.

Overall, this game is spectacular and i love it for how it is, but i know with adding new features you could increase the replay value by so much.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is not Minecraft. Beyond the aesthetic, this is a completely different game. Ultimately, for an early acces game, this is great, especially for a younger market that are showing interest in RPG style games. There is room for improvement, but on a whole it feels like more than you normally get from early access with a lot of meat on the bones and I'm looking forward to seeing the updates. For 15 bucks, get around it.

Obviously targetted at a younger market, the combat is a little reptitive and the only real objective is to upgrade your gear through a crafting system which is admittedly quite deep, but the pacing of the game is a little slow. There are a number of different armours and weapons that you can craft and use, regardless of your class, which is great, but farming the materials for these items can be quite laborious, bordering on tedious.

The RPG elements aren't that deep. Character progression is rather linear, with only minor choices at certain levels with a this or that" perk choice. The creative side of the game seems irrelevant to me

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Omg I love this game. I play this with my best friend who lives in another state, we can seamlessly play together in our own universe. My steam library totals over 200 games and I've been playing extensively for over 15 years, and this is one of my favorites. Here's what's good, and what's bad:
The good:
-multiplayer capabilities
-difficulty levels
-mage and archer class
-crafting
-building
-art (seriously, it's fantastic)
-first AND third person
-the bosses (I feel like a kid playing Zelda again ^w^)
The bad:
-the warrior class
-the third person mining/harvesting
-the sparsity of iron and gold on multiplayer worlds
-class limitations (there are only 3 :/
-no sprint (I'm a mobility enthusiest in games)

Yes this game is amazing, yes it is only in Beta, yes you SHOULD buy it.
My reccomendations for the developers:
Add more class variety
Add more progression
Add a story/more quests
Balance the warrior class (it completely relies on dodging)
Error 31 (my friends PC crashed and the world is now unplayable
Raise quality of loot in chests

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It just got released this morning and I'm going on 10 hours.

It is EXTREMELY addicting!

I am having so much fun so far and am really impressed with this game. Sale price of $11.99 on release and I've already got my money's worth.

Create a character, personalize it, pick your class, join your friends on an adventure through a mystical world made of many lands, fight so many different types of monsters and creatures and bosses, craft and upgrade new equipment as you progress, build houses or castles or whatever you please.

I'm very excited at the potential of this game and knowing it's early access and still will have more to come is even more thrilling. Stoked to see what this game will bring next but in the mean time I will enjoy the ride!

I highly recommend checking this one out, it is a lot of fun solo or with friends!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I spent a decent amount of time in this game and I would say, for the most part, I was happy however I'm not recommending this game due to the following:

1)The game was FAARR too easy and I can't stress this enough.
At level 17 with Iron level gear, pretty much all quality 8 (and it goes up to 30 I think) I defeated the level 30 boss without any issues. His whirlwind was hitting me for like 80 each assuming it even touched me as it was slow and easily avoided.
You might ask, how did you get to the final level 30 boss at level 17? Well, you simply need to equip a bow and you can kill any normal mob in the entire game. The pathing literally has the units running directly at you and if there is a gap in the middle or you are above them they just stop. If I keep going I will fall off the cliff
date: Guess I should stop and not find a way around this hole"\nIf the game never gave you experience I am 100% confident you could do the entire game at level 1 with a starting bow
recommended:
with ease.

2) There is basically no difference in classes.
Once you hit level 15 or 20 you can be 5% worse (in the same gear) than any of the other classes. (Warrior 5% worse than a Wizard for instance). Every level you increase all 3 of your stats.. there is no picking and choosing what to get better at to actually bridge the gap between your class and any other class.
Honestly
hoursPlayed: based on one of the talents that reduces magic damage taken by Wizards I consider them the BETTER TANK than a warrior. What?!\nThere is no gear or weapon lock outs. So while I'm not totally opposed to this it makes the lack of talent / class differences mean that a mage wearing plate + a melee weapon is the exact same thing as a warrior (and based on my previous point
voteText:
probably better).

3) The game has no challenges and/or different experiences **Not to be confused with #1**
To progress through the worlds you just need to collect 'Shards' which combine to unlock the doorway to the next area. How do you get these shards? Just kill stuff or mine... So for 20 something different worlds you just grind mobs basically.
If you grind mobs for long enough on world 1 you can progress right on through to world ~6 until you hit the next 'Shard color'. (Blue -> Yellow -> Green -> Red(Only 1 door) )
This is something I accidently did... just happened to collect 12 blue portal cubes and after porting through the first world I just walked over to the next portal and dumped in another 6... so yeah you can just skip entire 'worlds'.

tl;dr This game isn't what you might think it is... they want you to just mine like crazy and the classes / bosses / enemies were a total afterthought while making the game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I really wish steam had a sideways thumb!
Portal Knights is a digging adventure game in the same vein as Terraria or Minecraft.

Basic Gameplay Loop Mostly you will be hopping from portal to portal, leveling up, crafting new weapons and armor, and...well getting to the next portal. (also building things if you so desire). The game isn't an infinite world like Minecraft. Rather it's a bunch of randomly generated bite sized worlds strung together with portals. When you enter a new world...island.....shattered land...place, you'll have to explore and find the portal gate. The gate starts off empty though, so you'll have to fill it with portal stones." You get these stones by doing basically anything. Killing enemies
recommended: and finishing dungeons will sometimes land you some portal stone fragments. When you fill the portal with said stones
hoursPlayed: it opens up to another island. The islands are really small. I've only had one that had any kind of underground network. I think they could do with being a bit bigger.\n\nAtomphere and AestheticThe game has a very light hearted adventure atmosphere with a "cute" aesthetic. This is no voxel game though. The only thing that's square is the ground (and structures). I feel the ground has enough little details like grass and rocks to make it not stick out like a sore thumb. Worlds range from the usually foresty plains and deserts to toxic mushroom lands and tundras. The biomes are all filled with appropriate enemies and vegetation. The lighting is very nicely done

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The game is visually stunning, which was an extraordinary, but not unwelcome surprise from a game based on block building. Shadows are rendered magnificently, bloom effects and ambient lighting are done perfectly, though the different levels of Anti-Aliasing appear to have less of a change than one would expect.

Multiplayer through Steam was done well, and provides a nice and easy time connecting with a friend.

The game is fairly graphics heavy, though you can turn off many of the effects that can weigh down some weaker graphics cards.

The game was well designed up until this point, and I have seen absolutely no glitches or bugs occur in game. Perhaps I'm just not far enough, but everything so far appears extremely well designed, as if this was the initial release of a game, rather than an early access beta.

Aside from a few features I would like to see in the game, such as inventory stack manipulation (splitting stacks), this game has met my expectations, and blew them out of the water. But then again, those missing features... isn't that what Early Access is for?

If you like those sandbox building/exploration games like Minecraft, Terraria, TUG, and so many others, this game is certainly one to put on your wishlist. Already, I'm pleased with the game, and believe that it's worth every penny of the $14.99 it costs. Of course, if you're not sure, just give it some time until it reaches its official release.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is a beautiful game. The key for me was that it's LIKE Minecraft, only....better. Certainly it's a cube world, but with much prettier people and monsters. I also am a really big fan of the local multiplayer feature, which has allowed my whole family to cooperatively play together in the same world. My boyfriend and I had been searching for just such a game.

While the main objectives are simple (find the portals, activate them, visit all the islands, beat up the bosses), there is room to self-initiate other quests. I myself have set goals to craft all the best armor and weapons in the game, and build houses in each biome (using as exclusilvely as possible resources from that biome alone).

All the boss fights are repeatable, which is excellent given the invaluable item drops. I never would have gotten the equipment I have without them.

Needless to say, I am breathlessly awaiting the day when more content is released.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Portal Knights

If you like mining for materials, building structures, fighting mobs and falling off islands placed precariously in the sky then Portal Knights might be the game for you.

Character creation gives you a choice of 3 classes: Fighter, Mage or Archer and is pretty minimal. It's interface feels like you're creating a Nintendo Mii rather than creating anything complex and the characters have a rounded Lego look to them. Each class has abilities that they learn as they level up although some choices are somewhat confusing: the warrior uses STR as his primary stat so at level 15 he can increase his agility or int which are both pointless for him. The archer can increase STR (melee damage) or Int - again, both pointless?

Once you've created your character you're dropped on the starter world and given a series of quests to handhold you through the learning process of how things work. Once those have been completed the quests vanish and you're on your own from there to do what you want.

Once on an island defeating monsters (and, to a lesser degree, mining) gives you portal shards and these are used in the creation of portal stones via the crafting system and six of these special stones placed in one of the defunct portals around the island will power it up and permanently re-enable it for use. This gives you your gateway to another island and is Portal Knights method of progression.

There are 4 types of Portal stone that you can create and each colour stone takes a differing number of shards - the early starter worlds are accessed using blue portals and blue portal stones only take two blue shards to create each stone. Yellow portals start to appear around level 10 and yellow portal stones take 3 yellow shards so higher level portal stones take more materials to make. A portal will need 6 stones to activate it.

Travelling to another island opens up new blocks, ores, plants and mobs and each island can have multiple portals dotted around it. There's usually a dungeon too and these start off quite small but grow to a decent size on the later levels and are wonderfully lit. Mob variation within the dungeons seems a bit restricted though as far as I've seen - there's flying eyeballs, skeletons and..well, thats about it really.

Once you get to a certain point progression-wise you'll find one of the portals will take you to a special island. This only has a single mob on it and is a good, old fashioned boss fight. No spoilers here but its an interesting mechanic to drop in between the island exploring and isnt just a straight forward hold-fire-until-its-dead fight.

Crafting could probably do with a mention too. It reminds me somewhat of Starbounds crafting system in that you need specific machines to make different bits and those bits are used in other machines to make items (ie use a furnace to smelt ore > bars then use the workbench to fashion the bars into weapons).

When you craft something though it stays in the machine until you click it rather than going directly into your inventory. This is somewhat annoying but Im guessing this is so you can set up large batches of things that take a while and then go do something else while its crafting.

Overall its a very pretty game thats quite polished considering its just come into early access but obviously it still has its bugs. Quite a few people have had crashes/startup errors although the only ones I've personally seen have been a placement graphic bug (it was showing a doorway instead of the correct graphic when trying to place a chest) and a crash to desktop when I used a grenade to blow up a wall because I was too idle to mine it manually.

Tips:
-  Press M to get the map up. On the map screen clicking on a world will let you set that world as your home world or travel to it allowing quick travel to any world you've opened up. Clicking the tabs at the top of that screen will show you what mobs, plants and ores that world has. Useful if you're looking for something specific.
- On the map screen pressing the icon at the bottom right will port you to the entrance zone in point. Useful if you're stuck down a mine/on a cliffside and cant get back to the surface. Clicking the icon on the bottom left ports you to your home world (home world can be set from the map screen too).
- Things like doors/windows/furniture/statues in dungeons can be destroyed and picked up for use in your home. I found it particularly useful to rob the nearest dungeon of its doors to keep the drafts out of my new house.
- The level of the crafting machines define the number of recipes it has access to. Get the materials and upgrade them (up arrow icon at the far right of its interface) to get access to new, higher level stuff.
- Armour isnt class dependant. Any class can equip any armour/use any weapon.
- If you're a Warrior and having problems with flying things, carry a bow around as well as your main weapon.

Pros
+ Graphics engine is very pretty especially its lighting.
+ Music is also very good.
+ Crafting is in, working and already quite evolved.
+ Boss fights!
+ Leveling up and selectable skills for your character.

Cons
- Islands are miniscule and need to be considerably larger. This is my one major gripe about this game - there's hardly any exploration as you can pretty much see from one side of the zone to the other and cross it in about 60 seconds.
- Islands are also somewhat samey. So far I've seen 1 desert biome, 1 snow biome, 1 swamp biome and 11 green/leafy biomes. Hoping that gets a bit more varied in the terms of ratios of different types.
- The combat lock-on is annoying. I *know* I can hit tab to retarget. I dont need to be told every single fight.
- Cant rebind any of the keys.
- No real graphics options other than resolution,Window/Fullscreen and AA. There's also a Screen border x/y slider but I couldnt see that do anything?
- No run button. It feels odd to get attacked by something and then just nonchalantly wander away from it.

TLDR;
Very pretty game in the Cubeworld/Trove/Minecraft family. A few aspects of it are still buggy but overall its quite slick. Worth picking up if you're into those types of games (especially with the 20% off this week).

Its buggy (which is to be expected in an early access title) but its building a solid foundation for a great game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So after playing about 14 hours of this game, I can say I have a really good feel of this game.  I am very mixed on it.  The game is like  a mix of Zelda, Minecraft, and harvest moon.

Multiplayer:
This works OK.  My biggest issues is that everyone has to be in the same portal as the host of the game.  This is really annoying when trying to get mats from different portals.  The only fix we have come up with (my three friends who played 14 hours with me) is that each person who needs different mats leaves the game and goes into their own game to farm. Once they have the stuff they need they can then come back and join the host in their main server".

Visuals:
The game is visually appealing. It runs very well in 1080p
date:
but anything above that it starts doesn't translate properly.  Also has problems with alt tabbing out.  The screen goes to windows screen and cannot change unless you completely reload the game.  I also had some friends who couldn't even play the game because the graphics were stuttering or broken. The game needs major optimization.

Combat:
The battles and the monsters are pretty awesome.  I like the range of weapons you can use and how the combat flows. By weapon of choice by far is the bow and the sword.  The bow is good for long range and not taking a lot of damage.  The sword will make quick  work of a group of monsters. The diversity of the monsters is pretty cool changing from day to night.  I would like to see more.

Portals:
Each portal is pretty cool. They change in vegetation and the monster that inhabitants them.  They also seem to get progressively bigger as you go through each portal with is cool. The first portal is my base and house I have built up.  I would like to see this area changed so it is bigger.  Right now it is pretty small and if you get a number of farms going you run out of space quick.  I have had to clear and add extra blocks to the outside of the portal zone areas to fit stuff.

Controls:
I use a piece of software and have mapped my controller to play the game. I don't know why they haven't mapped a controller to the game.  It works perfectly with controller.

Action bar:
I have a love hate with the action bar.  I am not sure why potions or sharpening stones when placed on your action bar become circles??? I can select them when scrolling through with my mouse or using my quick key scrolls on my triggers that I have mapped on my xbox controller. They need to get rid of this.  It also took my buddies and I about 4-5 hours of game play before we figured out you have to have your weapon selected and click the hot key that you have your sharpening stones on to repair it.  We tried finding this information on the internet with no luck.  They need to make this more aware of how to do this or change how this mechanic works.

Building:
I love the range of the pickaxe.  One of my biggest gripes with Minecraft is that your hit box was so short. This game makes it very easy to mine/clear stuff that is far away or above your head.  Keep this up! It is very easy to build and create the different items you need to do this.  I have so far built a house and a castle.

Farming:
Farming works awesome in this game.  You can plant seeds and within an hour they are ready to be harvest. I have a beautiful garden going by my house that I have collected seeds from all the different portals.  My favourite are the cool big mushrooms.  The only other thing I would like to see is possibly pets or animals?  I don't know how you would integrate  them in the game.  Maybe as mounts or as a way to clear/collect stuff?  Maybe unleash a goat in your garden to collect all your cotton :)

Mining:
Mining works pretty good.  The only gripe I have with mining is that some of the items you can use to do special mining are junk. I keep going back to my copper pickaxe.  It mines the best and does the best job all around.  The mining claw is junk and the drill is junk.  It would be cool if the drill took out 8-10 blocks at a time for clearing big areas
recommended:
but it doesn't.  The claw also doesn't seem to really have any big benefit over the copper pickaxe.

Crafting:
Crafting is very easy to use. You can see what mats you need and get the gear going. The only thing I would really like to see is enchant able or magical gear.

Dungeons
voteText: and Bosses:\nThis is my biggest gripe. My friends and I were so excited when exploring dungeons and caves. Nothing was more of a letdown when getting to the bottom of a cave and breaking open a cache. What's in the cache you ask? Gold? Treasures? New items or equipment?  NOPE.  You got some potions and some mats that you can easily farm by yourself.  They need to change this greatly.  There is literally no point to exploring caves
helpfulPercent: spelunking
votesHelpful:
or beating bosses.  They need to change this.  They need to add more mini bosses that are harder to beat and that have a chance of dropping something that is RARE.  Not a potion of health or mana (which I rarely even use) or some mats that are easily collected by yourself.

Conclusion
The biggest draw to the game is the building/farming  and somewhat crafting side at this point. I have enjoyed those so far
votesTotal: but I find based on what they currently have
votesFunny: it will get old quick. The monsters and boss loots need to be beefed up and better gear drops need to be added.  Also gear needs to be upgraded a bit more.  It needs to be enchantable and a bit more variety to it.  Gemming would be a pretty cool feature.\n"

I was looking for a game for my wife and I to play with my 9 year old daughter; We found it with Portal Knights!

Portal Knights in essence combines a lot of aspects of other games I have played over the years into a pleasant little bundle that my whole family can actually enjoy. This game, I really recommend! <--

You can choose between being a warrior, an archer and a mage.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

24 hours in, and I'm ready to pull the trigger on this one. Portal Knights is a quality product. Since launch, it has been updated a million times, and improved SO much. 505 is killing it with this game.

Let's get this out of the way:

It's NOT a Minecraft style game
It's NOT a 3D Terraria

If you go in, expecting either, be prepared to be confused. It's an Action game, with crafting and building elements. Crafting is mostly for POTIONS, CLOTHING, WEOPONS, TOOLS, MAGIC, and other assorted items to help you kill the baddies. Crafting or building other stuff, can be skipped entirely.

It's HARD playing solo. Take your time, and don't just plow through the portals, you will get to a point where you suck HARD.  Best with friends, especially the bosses. Take your time, level up, and upgrade your gear as much as possible.

Portal Nights doesn't WOW me like other favorites of mine, but it keeps pulling me back, to try my hand at progressing... I feel like I'm just getting going, and I've got 24hrs, at $15. That's a WIN....

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Disclaimer
Ive had a few ask about the game so putting this up for my friends. =) I know quite a few of you are curators so bare in mind, I am by no means a professional reviewer. I just go from the heart and write as if I was leaving a message for a friend asking for an opinion.


If you like exploring, crafting and rpg elements its a fantastic game.
Over all for an Early Access it feels really complete. I think its a pretty casual game at this stage which I hope never turns into a grind-mare like Trove after their full launch. It's similar to other voxel sandbox games such as: Creativerse, Sky Saga, Trove, Oort Online now renamed Boundless. But I feel it's not geared towards building as some of those without time spent terraforming. =)

You can create 5 characters and 3 worlds and each character can enter any of those worlds and carry their inventory with them. Not sure if this is the case to enter friends worlds. But this would allow you to take a geared character with extra portal gems to a new world and unlock it all relatively quick. Be it for exploring, or harvesting, or just total destruction to farm out and delete. :D:

On the (M)ap you can fast travel to any island you've unlocked, your set Home or back to the starting point of the island you are currently on. Handy if say you dig down 50 blocks and don't want to make a way out. You also can choose to set any island to be your Home, just remember you'll have to move your storage.

Storage boxes can be made to allow for hoarding the world. Each tier allows 4 more slots from the last. Inventory itself is a little small considering you have many tools, spells as well as weapons to put in there.

Pro tip:
One of the complaints I saw a lot was lack of resources, and the first couple days I thought so too until I saw the resource locator you can craft. There are SO many resources buried in the islands.

The bottom line to me, in all honesty..
Those of you who knew how exited I was for Oort...I feel its what I wanted to see from it when I bought in at $53 last April. Which left me disappointed in everything including support that did not reply after 3+ months. On the flip side with Portal Knights, a member of their team actually commented on my screenshot which gives me warm fuzzies if i needed to actually contact them for support.

I know I forgot to mention some things I thought were cool, but such is life. Just ask if you have a question. =)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have only played about an hour and a half of the game, but from what I can tell, there isn't much too it.

You start out on an abysmally small floating island, and are presented three quests to complete in order to teach you the basics of the game. Make a pick axe, kill some mobs, create a portal.

The point of the game is to go to all the worlds and then kill the boss at the end, I guess. The systems in the game are very clunky and strange. Anyway, to the nitty gritty.

The Good
1. The game is very pretty and is visually impressive, for what it's worth.
2. The crafting holds promise for the future, but there is really no point to it other than upgrade your equipment and forget about it.
3. You can customize your character differently, so there's that.
4. There are 3 different classes, I'll touch on this later.
5. Can play first person or in third person mode, which is really nice option.

The Bad
--  Combat --

1. Auto Targeting is awful. It is a Tab-Targeting oriented combat, which doesn't really work out very well.
2. Can't move while attacking. You swing your sword/axe/mace and it moves you toward your targeted enemy a small distance, hopefully so you stay within hit radius.
3. Camera Locks in combat, and it's very bad. It zooms in and goes into a letterbox mode.
4. Automatic. You just right click and wait for the enemies lifebar to go away.
5. Clunky mechanics. You can't Evade attacks midswing, and must be standing stationary in order to execute an Evade.
6. You cannot attack a mob on a block higher or lower than you in melee.



Now, the combat could be worse, but it's also nothing special. It's extremely basic and feels very automated to the extent where you literally just hold Left Click and drink a potion once in a while.

--  Exploration/Sandbox --

1. Nonexistant. The Worlds" you go to are nothing more than tiny floating islands. By tiny
date: I mean depressingly tiny. Small enough to where you can explore the entire thing in 3 minutes.\n2. Uninspired. The worlds are all disconnected and isntanced chunks of land. There is no reason at all to ever stop and build
recommended: because you will leave the island in 7 minutes and be on your way.\n3. Linear. There is no need explore anything
voteText: get your portal made and then leave the island. There is nothing noteworthy to find and it leaves the adventure feeling dead and bland.\n4. The entire world is made the same every time. Same mob spawns
helpfulPercent: same layout
votesHelpful:
everything.
5. This game feels like the sandbox was an afterthought. You could play the entire game without ever crafting or building anything other than a crafting table.


--  Other  --

1. You cannot allocate your stat points when you level up manually
votesTotal: they are automatically allocated
votesFunny:
and the Skill Talents are boring and very dry.
2. The inventory/menu is tragic.
3. You cannot drop items or trade items. The only way to give another player an item is to put it in a chest for them to pick it up.
4. No Sprint/Run ability. Can't jump in combat
commentsCount:
can't look around in combat.

This game leaves much to be desired.

Suggestions
Add purpose

In order to progress to the next world
column16: require you to perform a task or defeat a mob
column17: complete a puzzle
column18: something in order for you to feel you are progressing towards something
column19:
not just killing some mobs to get your portal crystals and leave.

Seemless World

No portals. At all. The system is dumb and doesn't make sense in a sandbox game. Sandbox games are supposed to be an open world
column20: not a series of instanced islands (extremely small islands
column21: at that). Give a reason to build a base and crafting station. Perhaps create a "Peace Zone

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is a really enjoyable game and for it's first few days in early access it's really showing us what we've got to come. I;m not going to say that this is God's gift because yes, some improvements are needed, but again, not even a week in and it's already been addictive and enjoyable.

A lot of people complain that the maps are too small or that they don't see the point of setting up a base but I disagree. As you move through the game the enemies become stronger and it really calls for upgrading your equipment which can only be done at certain workstations after they have been upgraded. As for the maps, yes, they are small, but this is somethign that the devs can easily resolve, but the current state doesn't hinder the game.

The combat system has a familiar Legend of Zelda feel to it, which is great but definitely needs work.

All in all, the game hasn't been out a week but there is plenty to do and worth picking up with the 20% discount right now, definitely something to enjoy now and also keep an eye on for the future.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

At the moment the game is just average with a slight lean to below average. A lot of areas need fine tuning to push this game up into a state where it's worth buying.


1. Gets too grindy mid-game, after the second boss it's rushing to new islands JUST to grind ores to upgrade your gear. And the ratio of material to refined doesn't help. 16 gold ores for 1 gold ingot and 10 Wonder Wool for 1 Wool Cloth is just pointless fluff.
2. Needs UI improvements (auto sorting and the like)
3. Some balancing issues
4. The islands quickly become stale with no real reason to explore each one, just grind the important resources you need then move on.
5. The skill tree is unimpressive, just basic passive bonuses every 5 levels.
6. You can't assign stats upon leveling, it's automated to give 3 points in each plus 1 extra stat based on class.
7. The game would greatly benefit from some kind of recycling system. I'm sitting on all kinds of resources and items that I no longer need and there's nothing I can do with them, just throw them away to save chest space.
8. Needs more 'unique' content on islands to keep you exploring them, like minibosses, dungeons, events or quests.
9. There's several destroyed or damaged structures you find like houses and towers, but they only serve to have some crates to break or get some extra brick blocks. It'd be more enjoyable if they served a larger purpose.
10. I'm not enjoying the portal fragments, I was swimming in them because I had to spend so much time grinding materials to upgrade my gear I had the option to skip multiple islands.
11. Old islands resources become obsolete the further you progress into the game, making stocking up on cotton, copper, iron, stone, plants, etc pointless.


The pieces are all there, it's a just a matter of putting them together efficiency. I'm hopeful the Devs will continue to update the game and make this worth buying.
voteText: 33 of 47 people (70%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Gameplay + my thoughts below:

https://youtu.be/gmaW3fUwlRI

Portal Knights is a game with great potential. It's one of those games that time disappears. I've really enjoyed the game so far. The game is designed to be a coop experience but so far I've played it only solo and I've still be having a great deal of fun.
The combat seems similar to Zelda games with the lock on camera when you attack an enemy and then using this camera you can dodge away from attacks etc.
Bosses fun but simple, again reminding me of Zelda type bosses where they have one set weakness that you just need to exploit until you win.
The worlds are small chunks of floating biomes with different resoruces to be gathered in each one.
These environments look great and are stunning.
There are currently 3 classes to choose from near the start which so far I've only tried the ranger/hunter type character which I'm pretty fond of right now.
Theres no limits though from what I can tell towards using other weapons, my ranger has magic as well as his bow so there is room to customise your character as you wish.
You craft weapons, armour, tools and about anything else you wish to build from castles to simple cottages.
So far a great game and well worth its price. I'm looking forward to seeing the bright future for this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

while i still haven't completed portal knights and am only about halfway through all the worlds you can portal to, i'm in love with this game. it reminds me of creativerse but with a dark souls inspired combat system. being able to set any of the worlds i've discovered as my new home world is a nice touch. i haven't explored any of the multiplayer aspects yet, so i can't comment much on them except to say that i was excited by the idea of running through this game with a party of friends. my main character is a level 15 or 16 mage and i like the variety the game provides in terms of customizations. i assumed since i picked a mage that i wouldn't be able to wield the archer's bows or the warrior's melee weapons, but i totally could. i can even pick whatever kind of armor to wear that i want. if i want to be a mage blasting spells while shooting a bow and wearing heavy damage resistant armor, i can and i really really like that.
as for the crafting aspects of the game, most things need to be built at a workbench for most blocks and tools, or at an altar for your magic spells, armor, and weapons. there's also a furnace for smelting ingots out of ores and an anvil for making nonmagical weapons and armor. all of the crafting stations can be upgraded and by upgrading them, you learn new recipes for crafting more, bigger, and better stuff.
all of the enemies and the magic weapons/spells in the game belong to one of 4 elements. i'm not sure what they're called ingame, but it's your basic lightning, nature (earth), fire, and water elements-complete with weaknesses and resistances. in order to make elemental weapons and gear, you'll need to mine or kill enemies for special gems/crystals. the crafting costs get higher and higher for the better items/gear, but since armor doesn't appear to degrade and weapons/tools can all be repaired, you'll never have to make more than one of each. my favorite part of the game is the dowsing rod you can make that helps you find gems and ores across the various worlds.
in all, it's a great game-even more so for being in early access for a little less than a month. it's great to look at, fun to play, there's a ton to do and i imagine they'll add even more as it goes along. this doesn't feel like an early access game. it feels like it's already completed and i can't wait to see what else gets added

Early Access Review

The game is okay. I will make this a postive review, because I support these devolopers and the game.

First of all, the game has crashed like 4 TIMESS ON ME! Please... fix...

Things I noticed that need to be fixed a little:
- Give death a bigger penatly, because I have no fear of dying because you keep all your items and you just respawn 2 seconds later.
- Each block pretty much has the same noise when you break or place them
- The camera angles are odd at times, but for the most part okay
- Things get repetitive reallly quickly, and the worlds biomes/terrain are mostly the same
- Adding different types of tools or weapons (obviously that will come over time) i'm looking forward to that
- Make locking on to enemies disabled, or tweaked because its O.P
- Give enemies faster walk speeds, or high jumping, or being able throw object at you. Because when you're archer or mage you can just stack 3-4 blocks up and kill everything without getting injured at all, besides fire and lightning knights.
- Making islands bigger, with some more underground dungeons possibly.

Those are just some of my suggestions to the game. I willgive the game 8.5/10. Right now, it just isnt too enjoyable because it gets very repetative. But pretty good, make those suggestions a thing and the rating will be a 10/10 :)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Doing a quick down to the point review. im in the middle of my game and i need to finish my castle... so while stones being made im writing this!

:::::THIS REVIEW IS CURRENTLY ON RELEASE DATE:::::
`````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````
This game has a lot ahead of it. On release its very well optimized. 60 fps on max settings. No lag what so ever.

PROS
+first AND third person. switch at your will with mouse wheel. (push it in)
+LOVE THE CRAFTING! The crafting stations are upgradeable and easy ui
+portals are easy to make
+combat has nearly no flaws
+tools are repaired using a sharpening stone.. which only costs one stone to make atm... (might be a bit op)
+3 classes to pick from.
+armor has no durability what so ever.
+no death penalty at the moment.
+building in this game feels so amazing and easy to do (somewhat hard in first person)
+tutorial is simple and short
+the music feels like friggin fable music. i love it!
+all blocks are breakable with your hand
+leveling is rather easy and the skill system is beautiful but not very dynamic.
+from what ive seen mobs cant destroy blocks. so no griefing :D
+no fall damage

CONS
-somewhat grind of resources from mobs. not too bad at the moment...
-no armor customization (like dyes, paint. etc)
-not open world. only small islands you teleport between.
-no shops or npcs to interact with
-THE FIRST PERSON NEEDS WORK. combat and building is clunky and feels weird to use.'

MIXED
+- auto aim for combat is a huge factor. dont expect to require skill with an archer, the game does that for you.
+-for multiplayer i believe its only local or with friends. ive never played multiplayer yet so im going off what the menu says.
+-stuff like iron armor looks like its for a warrior class but yet its useable on all classes, and much better than subsequent mage/ranger armor.


ALSO: the community is so friendly, and they even have a discord channel. so you can just hop in and talk with people and get a world started!


i will update this as soon as i get to do more with it. right now im fending off elemental armor and slimes while trying to build a wall. ;)

EDIT: just killed the worm boss for the first time, the boss fights are intense!!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is the best Minecraft-inspired game out there, with some fun RPG elements and a unique feel to the world. There's a lot of potential where this game can go, and for an early access game it is really top notch.

If you like to build, especially with friends, and have some adventures through dungeons and exploring worlds, then this game is perfect. The classes and skills are fun, the combat is simple and easy to get a hang of from the start, and the different island biomes and aesthetic to the game are really well done.

It is a small world and short story overall (currently), so if you aren't into building and are looking solely for a solid RPG/adventure game then this may not be for you, but keep in mind that it is still early access and there is still a lot of room for this game to grow.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Note: Writing this review with 15.3 hours into the game. Some of it was spent with me AFK making food or tending my kids lol.

So far, the game is fun and enjoyable considering it's an Early Access game there are some flaws and bugs here and there obviously. You have 3 classes to choose from: Warrior, Mage, and Ranger / Archer. As of right now, I feel the Warrior got the short end of the stick from the 3. Since he's CQC and with the current combat system, the whole not being to move while swinging your weapon doesn't work too great. Now, going forward... The game starts you off on a small island with barely any monsters to fight so it's an introduction to the game.  Get some wood, make a workbench, kill a skeleton, grab some blue crystal shards and then form blue crystal cubes and rebuild the portal. That is practically what you will do to progress further into the other islands. For accessing the boss islands from what I've seen, instead of blue shards, they're yellow shards. The shards are relatively easy to farm but, I try not to rush through each island considering each island has it's unique resources to farm. The game is not difficult for me, for others I don't know but, I enjoy it because I play it to enjoy the scenary and explore each island and find the hidden treasure chests that they have. So for those who have been rushing through, you probably missed a few. I won't say it's a mandatory thing or the reward from the chests is something amazing but, it's something to do instead of just rushing through to reach the final boss and say... oh well, now what?

I just had my first co-op experience today with a buddy of mine. So far, I feel there should be a trade function or a drop item button, because as of right now... the only way you can give an item to a friend is by placing it in a chest and having your friend get it from the chest. That can be really annoying especially if you pick up some loot that he or she was getting from a loot chest and you happened to be close by and it goes to you instead.

First boss was nothing too special but, I will say I died the first encounter because I wasn't sure what to expect lol.

Cons:

Auto-lock camera combat needs work.

Progression to other islands are too simple (reduce the drop rate on shards to where it's not so easy or... add a mini-boss spawn when you are opening a new portal to the new zone... something along the lines).

Warrior needs some work, seems slighty weak for the current combat style.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

At the time of writing this review the game is still in Early Access.  I'm usually really hesitant about opting into Early Access games but I was pleasantly surprised with this one.  I'm at about level 13 and so far the single player has worked fairly flawlessly and I'm loving it.  I've definitely gotten my $11 dollars worth from it and I intend on playing it much more and updating the review as I go.   If you loved Minecraft you will probably enjoy this one since it feels to me similar but improved. The graphics are updated, the level music is great, the rendered levels are small but really cool (one thing I hope going forward is they make them a bit larger so you can really get lost in each one.)

Final Early Access Update (Having Unlocked All Worlds and Reached the Gate)
I would still recommend this game especially at the price as it's giving us a sandbox minecraft style block construction here on steam. It's a great base and I'm hoping to see more great additions in play mode to the game as it gets developed.  Right now there is a decent start and I'm having fun with it and I've already gone away from it and decided to come back and build or play a bit more.  The development team has been really interested in taking player suggestions and listening to complaints in the community and I feel they are really trying to create a friendly player base for the game so I'm very hopeful that this game will continue to grow it's player base and get better in the future.

Now the sandbox looks rely nice for building small houses and interiors. But needs work on the exteriors like plants, trees, patches and some water cud be nice. So in conclusion the game is not bad just shallow and i don’t know if early access can excuse that i hope that they keep working on it. so yes get the game but don't expect 500 hours of entertainment.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First impression & about the game:
Wow, absolutely impressed by this gem. I saw the title and pretty much blew it off but one day I clicked it, watched a video, and instantly bought the game. It's butter smooth and is well made. There's 3 different classes (typical mage, archer, knight). You can take your progression on any character and join any friend or start a new world. Each world has many different locations you can go through by entering the portals you complete which advance in level (eventually you'll find multiple portals on maps). Each location is a good standard size but what's really cool about this sandbox is every location has different enemies, materials, build, etc. It seems like the farther I get the bigger the locations get also.  You can set any main location as a home world and travel between the locations (each location has a landing pad where you spawn, you can also craft these). On top of that, all the items you gather and craft, you can shuffle around to other locations and continue to build upon that location in your world to expand it, giving it that sandbox quality. ANYTHING and EVERYTHING can  be destroyed and built.

Combat:
The combat reminds me of The Legend of Zelda: The Windwaker. It has the widescreen focus lock effect and you can roll and dodge. I'm hoping they give players the option to turn it off. I don't enjoy using it with the archer but with mage and knight it works great. You can roll in combat. Each weapon attacks differently (by arc, speed, damage, etc). I have a knight and health + mana bar. Spells are crafted and can be use by any class.

Loot/Craft/Items:
So far I've noticed potions, materials, ingredients, misc, etc when looting enemies. You can loot objects like in minecraft by attacking them, broken items are salvaged. Weapons and armor are made by crafting and also have different stats and effects. ONLY weapons have durability and lose full power when depleted but can still by used. So far I've noticed the more you hit with an item the faster the  durablility depletes. There is equipment/talens that gain durability back and help not deplete durability. I've noticed  that slower weapons (typically stronger than fast) SLOWLY deplete durability yet hit very hard. These types of weapons seem to be the best for keeping durability high or by running equipment with durability stats.

Leveling/Stats:
When you level up, you click the add stats and it's automatically done for you depending on your roll as of now the current state. You can unlock a row of talents and switch between them once the level has been reached. It's impossible to mess up your character stats. Your equipment plays a huge roll depends on your survivability which I kind of like but leveling does increase stats. Stats range from STR, DEX, INT. As for equipment, you'll see crit damage, crit chance, dodge/evade, speed, mana, health, regen, and special stats like mining, durability, and so on.

In it's current state, I feel like the game is completed to be honest. The art style is grabbing and the combat is very fluid. It's very afforadble and very fun in its current state, I HIGHLY recommend it. It's only $15 (I'd pay $30 for it considering most games made today are terrible).

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I bought this quite early on with some friends as we really liked the idea behind it. At first it was a bit awkward and there were a fair few bugs (it's early access so that's expected), but it's certainly fun and has even more potential. We played for about 18 hours before we kind of got bored of its problems and wanted to wait for an update to fix them. And here it is! We're going to play it again now, and I thought it'd only be fair to recommend it now while it's on sale. It's worth sticking with this game, especially if the developers are going to stick with it too; this update has certainly addressed a lot of the problems that we were having at the start, and I'm looking forward to seeing where it goes in the future.

EDIT: after playing it for some time with the newest update, I think that it has improved massively. It feels more like an RPG, with better loot and harder enemies (the ghost island gives you the opportunity to fight hard enemies and earn some loot way ahead of your level), and it's still beautiful as a sandbox. There are still some bugs, being early access (but the auto-save seems to work well, as it's crashed a few times and I've never lost anything), but it's less buggy than it was.

At this point, there are good points and bad points, which I think it's only fair to list, if only to put forward my opinions on the early access:

PROS:
+Beautiful game, great design and lighting.
+Fun fighting mechanics and great variety within classes (although Melee still seems at a bit of a disadvantage).
+Fun to farm for resources and loot. Incorporating more random drops in the last update, having to search for certain recipes and armour sets, has made playing much more rewarding.
+Good progression. You always feel like you're going somewhere, making your way towards something, a new weapon, or a boss, or some rare armor.
+Events in the latest update completely changed the feel of the game. It's a chance to test yourself against harder enemies and get worthwhile rewards. This update came with better loot drops as well, so certain enemies will randomly give you great stuff.
+Island size. I'm putting this in here because some people say (or used to say) that the islands are too small. I don't think they're too small. Some of them are very large. I think that they're the perfect size (and depth) for this type of game - you need to explore them and move on, not get stuck on one island for too long wondering if you've missed anything.

=Variety. This is a pro and a con. The variety of islands is really good, overall - there are several islands types in each section of the game (between bosses). Finding a new type of island is exciting, and exploring the first couple of that type is good because they do have slightly different resources. But there are too many of some types in each section, and eventually, you portal into a new island, realise that it's got the same resources and enemies as the last two, and don't bother to explore it. This is usually only for the last few islands before the boss, after you've already got all the resources you can get in that section of the game, but I'm sure that as the game develops the variety will, inevitably, improve.

CONS:
-Some bugs, getting stuck in chests, crashes, but it's to be expected in early access (and nothing gamebreaking).
-Repeated islands, as aforementioned.
-Dungeons aren't great; the first time you do a type of dungeon, it's fine, but there isn't much variety (much like the islands they're on), and the loot isn't really good enough to make it worth going through one.
-Sandbox controls. Block placement and breaking isn't always smooth, and items have a tendency to bounce around into odd places; it needs some tweaking. But variety is good so far and you can build some cool stuff.
-Poor wiki. I know that this isn't anything to do with the game, but as the game becomes more like an rpg, with things like random drops, it's harder to know what to look for without a decent wikipedia or forum to help you out (think: Terraria). I suppose it depends how much random drops come into it, but to develop as an RPG it's probably going to get more complicated, and looking things up to do is part of the fun.

TL;DR: before the update this game was ok, neither a great RPG, nor a great sandbox. Now it's really showing us what it's capable of, and it's pretty good at both. I hope it continues to get better, but it's worth playing NOW.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

You like Minecraft's building system?
You like the combat system of Zelda with a touch of Dark Souls in it?
Then GET.THIS.GAME!
Portal Knights is- as you might've guessed- a game with an open world sandbox that has a very nice action combat coming with little RPG elements here and there.
You start out on a rather peaceful island that gives you a checklist of stuff to do to teach you the very basics of the game,
which works very well if I may mention that!
But once you advance from that point, you're greeted with a set of numerous islands which all represent different biomes.
Different biomes meaning different enemies and different resources- both for building and fighting.
So you're bound to explore more to discover and achieve more.
It's very nicely balanced on the resource factor, while the combat part is still very easy- to me at least.
The further you progress, the harder it gets.
And on every 10th-ish island you visit, you may stumble upon a boss fight.
The bosses feel very Zelda like, all having their own mechanics on how to beat them.
For example, the first boss.
A gigantic worm that spews toxic goo.
Instead of instantly attacking him, you'll have to bring down his defense.
He spawns multiple worms and maggots that will attack you, except for one of them.
That one is it's tail, that you have to attack to bring down the boss' defense, so you can deal damage.
Neat, isn't it?
The bosses themselves aren't really hard, but it's nice to see how well the combat system is working along.
But don't think you can just stand there and defend from whatever the game throws at you!
Instead of giving you a shield, the game gives you a quick dodgeroll, which you can and have to use to avoid incoming attacks.
It keeps you own your toes and if you don't pay attention, you will get mauled by multiple enemies at once.
Now, from the combat and exploration part, down to the building!
I'm honestly surprised by the options the game gives you in this very early state.
Speaking of an early beta range, Portal Knights offers you lots of room for building and decoration.
Those who are unexperienced get greeted with some ruins of older buildings here and there, which they can either restore and make themselves at home, or take inspiration (and building material) to make your very own creation.
For those who are experienced architects on block basis (like me), there's still quite some stuff to play around with.
I for one, have built myself some cottages here and there, some castles, and even own dungeons, putting lots of detail in every single one of them.
And that's not even the start.
But wait- Multiplayer?
NEVER been easier.
Upon starting your game, either loading one up or starting new, you can set your game to private, friends only, or invitations only.
Meaning, when you start your game, you're given the choice to play by yourself, or host a game for free, for which you can adjust the settings for your friends to be able to join whenever they'd like, or you being the bouncer of your game by having the power to invite people to it, for them to be able to join.
Quick, handy, just what I want from a Multiplayer in this kind of game.
It's true, the game isn't very big yet, and it is really easy, but the developers are always happy to receive suggestions and they are always working on it.
You can feel the love that is put into the game with every single update you witness, if you have played it already.
For newcomers, the same goes to you.
Kudos to 505 games on this point.
They put the right people on the right game to make it evergrowing, while including the community to a reasonable, well weighed out extent.
This game gets a 8/10 from me, because what it does, it does damn good.
And room for improvement is always on it's way to getting used to every last bit.
Grab this game, guys.
Damn sure worth it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Portal Knights

Where to Begin …. this is my first review, if it wasnt for laziness I wouldve written at least a dozen reviews on truly deserving games, this is one of them


TL:DR

Great game for this price, already enough content to warrant the price and a solid early access, don’t even wait for it to go on sale or come out of early access, buy it now.



I have never played minecraft, apart from briefly years ago during alpha/beta so I cannot really compare nor do I like too really.



Graphics:

“Cutesy” non offensive, children can murder monsters without crying or getting upset. Just watch any video, not much more to say.



Character classes:

Somewhat limited, melee is really underwhelming, almost pointless, choose a warrior and just use a bow was for me much better than swords etc. Have not tried mage.

Levels go up to 30 currently, this game is less about levelling though and there is virtually no customisation options for levelling up, just more health/stats etc with “perks” every five or ten levels.

This are could do with a little more fleshing out but it is minor as it is not that kind of game where levelling up is paramount.



Monster variety

Pretty good, different “Biomes” have different monsters including night time harder monsters, bosses are somewhat easy although I struggled on the last boss a lot, currently 3 major bosses, again for me this game is not about a massive challenge against uber bosses instead they are gate keepers to further regions.



Biomes/Regions

Around five or six different types of regions currently, the worlds are relatively small but there are a lot of them (44 out of 47 for me IIRC) I do not find the small worlds an issue personally



Crafting

So many different options of crafting, if you are a mage I think you will need to rely on mining/crafting a fair bit more than melee/ranged but have not tested this. Quite a few different types of tools weapons and armour can be created.

There are many types of blocks to create homes/buildings etc but the higher level blocks need a considerable amount of mining to create large dwellings



Farming

This is one area I really hope gets fleshed out, there are loads of seeds to forage and plant but honestly there is at the moment little point in doing so as I comfortably “completed” the game so far with almost zero need for farming, the potential for this side of the game could be great though and plants/tress seem to grow in real time.



Endgame

This is what interests me, I am level 27, comfortable enough to go anywhere and defeat anything without too much difficulty leaving me free to now play the way I intended to play, I love building homes and farms and crafting the land around me, this aspect of the game is almost limitless in that respect although interior decoration cannot be “used” by your avatar and again currently is somewhat limited

reviewText:
Early Access Review

For the one hour I have played I feel I should give a fair warning to those thinking of grabbing the game. So if you want to support these type of sandbox games then I'd strongly suggest playing and supportting these developers to see more of these games.

Pros:
-Amazing graphics and style
-Very good crafting system for an early access game.
-Building in this game could use some more options but so far so good.

Cons:
-Combat could use some work.
-Crafting lacks some complexity but its expected...
-The map sizes are small.

So overall if you caught any interest in the game it is on the sale still as of the date of this review and would recommend it. Going back to the pros the game offers so much for just entering steam and it has so much mmore potential to become of the top games but this is why. Sandbox. It is a sandbox game and has the opportunities to expand on any aspect of the game. While the freedom of a sandbox game is already there. there are many options missing like a trading system for co op/multiplayer. Also, the lack of a skill tree or rather a more complex combat system pulls the game back a bit. Moreover, it feels more generic as the map sizes tend to all be small so it takes a bit away from the exploration aspect of the game.

Final Verdict:
I'd recommend this game as of now it still offers plenty to satisfy its price value. The crafting, combat, and map size can all be fixed and improved over time. I have faith in this developer and hope to see great updates very soon. Hop into the game now and see it grow into an amazing game!

Early Access Review

This is a particularly good cross between Zelda and Minecraft, making it a fun and easy game to pick up and go. Having put nearly 7 hours into it straight from turning it on, I have to say it captures you and makes you want to play more.

A few things I have noticed though:

- Dodging is a tad too slow
- When you level up, you should be able to pick the attributes you wish to level up rather than which class you chose
- In co-op, if one person goes through the portal, you both have to travel through

Overall I do recommend this game to anyone who fancies a light RPG to play every now and then. 8/10.

Early Access Review

-Plays thinking it's like Minecraft, Trove, and Terraria

Overall, the game itself is much different than I thought it would be.

Pros

-Armor and weapons based on the characters

-No loot is lost when killed
-Bosses are somewhat unique and fun to fight
-Leveling system is good, takes a little bit of grinding and is best with friends
-Graphics are somewhat nice

Cons
