-FPS is somewhat bad unless graphics are turned down (although this might just be me)
-Not sure of what else to state at this time, will update later.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nA fun sandbox game, which has a lot of potential. The item art and graphics in general are top notch, and the game has a lot of interesting areas to explore. Most of the improvement that needs to be made is in terms of the interface and the RPG mechanics, such as adding more skills or stat variations, as currently the major benefit of leveling up is the boost to stats (the skills are mostly minor passive benefits.) You can craft usable skills as well, but there is also a low amount of variety here. I'd like to see debuffs/buffs and auras that reserve mana, etc. Perhaps these are unlocked later on, but I'm 10 hours in and have yet to see them. Overall, I'm excited to see where the game will go and hope the devs have major improvements in mind as the base gameplay is very strong!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I won't lie, this game has its problems, its glitches, and general dissapointments at times, such as not being able to make full use of my 144hz monitor as the game will have rubberbanding issues when running at 144fps. The combat isn't the most in depth and yes, I made a warrior character and I realize that they are practically useless when compared to the mage and archer class, but that adds a challenge right? A lot of people point out these among many other things you can complain about the game saying the game is bad, or it doesn't have enough content, as far as I'm concerned the only thing that they really do have to do something about is the lack of it really being a sandbox game. What makes a sandbox game a sandbox game is when you have the freedom to build whatever you want however you want, and while it does have this, the fact that you don't have a hub world that you can travel back to, and the inability to travel back to previous worlds, does kind of reuin that experience for me. However, what I think most people are overlooking is the price, at the time of writing this review and when I bought this game, the game is $13.59 CAD which is pretty damn cheap for me, I don't expect much out of games fairly inexpensive and still in Early Access, which means they'll improve it, so far I've been having a lot of fun and have had a seemless experience in Co-op.

If you are someone who feels like they need a perfect game no matter what the price is, you shouldn't be looking into early access, and to everyone who has already bought the game and is upset, it will  improve, look at Ark, it has undergone massive changes and is one of my favorite games on steam *despite the horrible optimizations* so just wait it out if you think you might not enjoy it.

*Side note*

This is my first review, I don't really know what I'm doing XD

UPDATE: They have fixed the stuttering issue with monitors with a refresh rate over 60hz, as well as the graphical error I was getting where I could only select low for textures. There are few things I feel that need to be fixed now, the only major thing I really think of right now is the lack of ability to return to previous worlds.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A Brilliant 3D Cartoony RPG, Fantasy, Magic, Action Adventure Randomly Generated World game in which you can play as one of the three typical Medieval RPG Fantasy classes, Warrior, Ranger and Mage. Fortunately you can use weapons and abilities of other classes allowing for fun creativity, however the class effects your focus combat style.

One thing to note is this game is sandbox, so you can do the standard dungeon crawling, monster battling or you can be a village builder, explore all the worlds, or even start a little garden to grow things.

This game is very fun and pretty, it's timeless cartoony graphics give it a beautiful yet ageless look and it's gameplay allows for alot of fun. Worlds are different from the universe you make and spawn in, each world brings in new biomes, resources, enemies and structures with over 50 worlds to explore. The Combat is very exciting, when entering in battle while in 3rd person mode goes into this cinematic camera mode in which allows you to dodge and dash around your enemy as you attack them. 1st person mode makes it a standard first person hack and slash.

The classes are really fun to play as, a great thing is that weapons and items aren't class restricted however if they are not your ideal class they won't be as strong as they can. Warriors do the standard epic sword swinging, shouting and brute force, Rangers do the standard bows/crossbows from a distance or up on top of structures as they pick off their enemies one by one, using agility to their advantage, and Mages do the standard Wand attacks, spells and potions in which Mages can have a large array of epic spells like lightning, fireballs, healing etc.

A great thing about this game is that you can jump to new universes to start in new generated worlds again and keep leveling up your character and getting new resources so it easily has endless fun. Co-op Multiplayer is intergrated into this game so that you can play by yourself, with a friend or on a public universe if you wish in which you can do what you can but with your friends/posse and become efficent monster battlers, structure builders, explorers etc.

I know this game is in early access and will change a lot, and I am so excited to see what changes come. Hopefully they keep them coming fast, because I don't really want to stop playing this game.

Amazing game. Really enjoyed it, and honestly cannot wait for more content to come out!

Quick tip for the developers from a co-op experience standpoint over 16 hours of gameplay: We kinda struggled to get enough bars for gear, weapons, tools and so on. We haven't even crafted decorations or anything really aside from gear! We scavenged it all from dungeons, and upgraded everything apart from the work bench to max iron tier. Playing as a duo was challenging, especially since the worlds and therefore resources are extremely limited, so maybe lowering the sky-high costs of crafting bars would help in the end game. I can't imagine what will come after titanium and how many hundreds it will cost to craft a single bar! :D

Other than that... Love it! Great job and keep up the good work! <3

Early Access Review

I have completed this game trough twice. Once with the warrior and the second time with the archer. Good fun with some familiar game mechanics that I enjoy as a fan of minecraft.

Some things that could use improvements.

-Melee weapons need to be stronger (Ranged weapons seem to be as strong or stronger. Found myself using the bow as the warrior)
-Too easy most of the time. Bosses are very simple to beat.
-Mining for Gold and Titanium takes a VERY LONG time to collect enough. I would prefer that it be more scarce whilst needing less to craft the corresponding items.
-Matchmaking with random players!! Get it in there!

All in all a great game! Looking forward to future updates!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I don't often comment on games and especially not early access games but I'd really like to say that this game is fantastic for the price. This is everything an early access game should be! It's playable, engrossing, relatively stable and complete in that no content needed to play the game is missing.

The most common gripe I've been seeing is that there is a lack of purpose and I think those people are confusing progression with purpose. Unlike Minecraft, you don't start the game with the ability to collect and use various materials. The purpose, however, is exactly the same - do whatever you want. The progression determines what you can do and how long you have to play before you can do it but the purpose is the same. The system of progression keeps things fresh! You collect new materials to build new weapons and armor to fight new enemies and bosses to find new materials. Please just keep in mind that the progession is to keep the things that are normally very mundane about Minecraft new and exciting but that the progression is not the purpose!

Anyways, I just thought I'd say my piece on the matter and really hope that the developers keep at it!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Entertaining, immersive and beautiful. Nintendo style graphics with a fighting system that copied Zelda.

Fun to explore Voxel sandbox maps. They arn't huge but they are big enough to be satisfied and the different worlds have different terrain, giving the game a different feel each time. I love the snow ones!

You can portal back and forth the worlds with no penalty or cost. No penalty when you die either.

RPG element is fine and addictive. You level up, craft better and better gear, weapons, and can build your own house and settlement. Different worlds within portals have different materials. This makes you jump between them ever so often.

The first two bosses were fun and reminded me again of playing Zelda (I haven't gotten to later bosses yet).

Difficulty is at a good level, not too hard, not overly easy.

Cons:
It can feel a bit repetative or grindy at times, especially later on in the game. Not enough to detract from the fun gameplay though, except in the last stages of the game. The final armour set is very grindy. You will have to invest quite a lot of time mining materials if you want the most powerful gear end game.
Not much point to keep playing once you reach max level and killed all the bosses.
No friendly NPC characters. Would be cool if there are a few worlds with NPC villages. These NPCs could also give out quests that reward you with a large amount of building blocks.
Feels a bit like it's targeted at a younger audience.

Overall:
I am happy with my purchase.
I can't wait to see further updates to this game and how this game develops.
So far this game has had me glued to my computer. Really absorbing.

Update: 12 hours in I killed the final boss at level 23. I did not craft the final set of gear and weapon. I ended up skipping quite a few worlds. The final boss was way too easy and disappointing. I was expecting an epic battle. Nothing much to do now but to wait for updates.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

For 15 bucks, it's not a bad game. It's very small though. The islands aren't nearly big enough for my liking. There are 44 islands broken up into individual stages which is fine but the islands are all too similar structurally. Towards the end of the game, they're broken up a bit more but still fairly solid. There are 3 islands dedicated to boss fights which is cool but the boss fights themselves weren't especially interesting. Just your normal boss battle fodder.

The combat gets repetitive after a while. I can only speak of the mage class as that is all I've played. They tried to break it up between a few different playstyles but ultimately, you're just mashing the same few buttons and/or holding left click until everything is dead. You get your main attack and then you can craft some spells but those are ultimately useless except the healing spell. You end up doing more damage with your wand/staff if you match it with the weakness of whatever you're fighting.

The gathering/crafting mechanics are solid though could use a bit of work still. An example would be after you've moved on from your first set or two of armor, you'll no longer need the materials used to craft those for the next sets however mobs all the way to the end of the game drop materials used to craft the lowest set of armors for no reason other than to fill your inventory. Each new set should require materials from previous sets to make the gardening mechanic actually worth while. Mining is great and works well here as you have to be mindful of the danger of falling off the island if you dig too deep. I would however, like to see the multitude of tools go away. Just have a pickaxe only and maybe the drill. There's no reason to have that many tools for such a small game.

The building aspect is something I didn't really get into because I just didn't really appreciate the small nature of the islands and the fact that I couldn't keep mobs away from me and my build. I tried to build but ultimately just stopped as I got annoyed that mobs would still spawn in and around my home. It's nice that it's there but there was no real benefit to having it in my opinion.

For what it costs, it's not a terrible game but it definitely has a ways to go before I'd ultimately recommend it to anyone.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I find this game hard to recommend. I came to this game expecting a minecraft clone with a bit more direction and better combat. I was very quickly disappointed. I have played this game for almost 3 hours per class (9 hrs total) I've gotten all to level 10 starting a new world each time.
Although the game looks like a hack and slash, it's nothing more than a tab targetting with a few dodge mechanics. You don't get to aim where to shoot. You aim what to hit. Then it locks and you can look where ever you want it will still shoot that monster. press # for your spell cast it then go back to your main weapon... This becomes a real issue when fighting multiple monster, You have to spam tab to switch targets or right click to untarget. And once you're not targetting an enemy, you can't roll... you can only jump, which unfortunately doesn't make evading easier.
Adding on to the tab targetting, some weapons (staff) has very slow projectiles. So you'd want to aim where the monster is going instead of where they currently are. Unfortunately you can't do that because it's locked. So smaller monsters that move side to side can easily dodge your attacks and you have no way of hitting them unless they stop moving or use an entirely different weapon, either melee or a faster projectile weapon (wand/bow).
Why does the screen turn to wide screen during combat? I don't know if they do it for aesthetics or to save GPU resources but it's a pain to deal with. Especially when you have to right click repeatedly to target other mobs. This makes your screen so annoying. And on that note, I get a bit of frame drop during combat. This only happened when I started using staff on my mage.
Building is ANNOYING. Building in 3rd person is absolutely horrible, misplaced blocks everywhere. Building in 1st person is pretty bad too. For some reason, I feel like I'm crawling on the ground when I'm on 1st person. The block you're holding at first person is far too large and blocks a lot of the screen.
I didn't get to unlock a lot of the portals. But from as far as I've travelled, the maps are relatively small. You dig for a few minutes and you'll fall to your death. You walk straight nonstop and you'll fall to your death again, in a few minutes. Exploring has become nothing but Look at your map, count how many portals there are, and find them. Once you do, you can instantly teleport to what ever destination it has. Worlds are only there as a resource. Once you've exhausted the easily accessible resources (iron, emeralds, coals, etc.) from the surface, there's not much point in digging deep to search for them since there's probably another planet that has them.
Crafting takes an unnecessary amount of time. It's unrealistic to expect something built instantly. But it's a game, in my opinion, there shouldn't be any need to have to wait 2 minutes to craft 9 copper bars.
Weapons only differ slightly. The only difference between weapons are appearance, damage, and attack speed. As a warrior, I've tried all the copper weapons (knives, long swords, axes, scythes, etc) Knives are just long swords that swing faster. And scythes are just long swords that swing slower. Axes are just over head animation with slightly more damage and slow swing speed. If you hold your attack button, then use the hot bar to switch weapons, the animation will persist while swinging at a faster/slower speed with the new weapon. Mages have staves and wands. Staves attack slow and wands are fast. Wands deal less, staves deal more. Oh and one more annoying thing, is when staves miss, they hit the ground and they break them. That leaves a lot of holes on the ground. And a lot of dirt in your inventory. The spells are boring. They're all very similar. Use them when they're off cool down to make the battle slightly more interesting to either deal more damage or heal a bit. Then switch back to your main weapon to continue attacking. Spells are easily craftable but use up mana far too quickly even as a mage. Regardless of the class you play, the playstyle is more or less repetitive. Left click until the enemy starts their attack animation, then you roll to the side. Issue comes from when you're attacking multiple mobs, then the difficulty ramps up, not cause of the game, but cause you'd also be fighting against the interface.
Freedom to customize the character as you wish would be a great addition. Leveling up is just you putting a skill point to a predestined allocation. There's hardly any customization with character builds. Skills you get every 5 levels are boring (at least lv 1-10)
There are probably a few things that peeved me about this game but I can't be asked to write any more. The first few hours of this game was definitely enjoyable. But then it falls into the same boring repetitive thing that you'd need to do to progress. Grind. Mine resources. Move to the next portal.

The game shows a lot of promise. I would prefer to be able to fight more freely instead of having my hand held so my attack would always hit. A few more attacking animation would be great, have it randomized so the combat doesn't get too stale too quick. Spells are extremely lack luster. Would like to have more customization with builds and have actual skill tree that has branches for a more unique character build.

Building houses are generally pointless. First person mode feels like you're crawling in the ground. Building is a chore.

Fix those problems or even some of them and I will change my review to a more positive one.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Looking for a helpful review look no further. This game is fun, has minor bugs but they can be over come with some patience. The worst bug I found while playing was the fact that my character would continue to run forward after I had stopped holding down the W key, which then led to me running through a mountain into a dungeon surrounded by Fallen Squires. Exciting. But for all these fun mishaps that happen there is only one major flaw in this game I think. That is the fact that it takes 20 gold ore to make one bar when it takes 10 for iron and like 5 or something for copper. 20 ore is ridiculous . It takes about 20 minutes lets say, to find enough ore for one bar. You searched the map found a big deposit, it had like 23 nice start right well now your running looking for more, wait a minute you cant find any. Well you start fighting a mirror golem and bam you see a couple of gold ore in the ground. You kill the golem and run over there to get that gold. You mine the top 3 and realize thats it. Unless you are ready to mine out the entire world I recommend getting one character. So the classes are Mage, Ranger, and Warrior. They are pretty self explanatory and all have special talents and uses. The system for leveling is quite easy to understand and amazing to say the least. While playing the game you collect portal shards to travel the worlds (great idea on the game devs parts). With new worlds comes harder foes, cooler castles, better portal shards, and most of all resources. Also multiplayer is only on LAN servers. I hope that gets changed to online. Also if the developers could make a trade system like a world market where players can sell items for coins that would make a great twist and allow them to forever change the world of portal knights. :D

10/10 would review again!!!!!!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is everything early access is meant to be.

The game itself nails the core mechanics and runs smoothly.
It's fun and doesn't feel extremely clunky.

The devs have said that they would like to release major content patches every 4-6 weeks for at least 6 months.
They are listening and have addressed that things like the challenge of the game and other complaints are being addressed right now.

If you're concerned about this being another indie dev that is going to take your money and bolt, the publisher 505 Games is the publisher behind Payday 2. They have funding to finish the game and finish it right.

Right now there's around ~20-25hrs of gameplay from 1-30, assuming you discover all the islands and get end game gear. After that it's a block building and alternative character game.

Considering that most $60 AAA titles only have <10hrs of gameplay through the whole game, I would say $15 is a hell of a good deal for a fun game.

Early Access Review

Let me start off by addressing that even though I'm recomending this EA game it does not mean I think you should purchase it in the state it is in now unless just to show support for the project. I have not played hours of the game ,because it did not need that kind of time investment to get an idea of what shape it currently is in. Now with that out of the way  I'll put down some pros & cons.
Pros
+ Combat system is fun ,and is clearly akin to that of 3d Zelda games which given the graphical style of the game fits perfectly.
+ Classes though not need are a nice add on to this style of game ,by which I mean the whole Minecraft trend.
+ Crafting is easy to access ,and doesn't require any guides to makes items as the recipes are listed in the crafting  stations.
+The leveling system was a nice touch that when completely flushed out will add something more to the game ,and helps give a better blend of RPG & Voxel games.
Cons
- The maps are extremely small to the point that you can travel one end to the other in seconds.
- Though it doesn't make or break the game everything being blocky could hurt the game when compared to other voxel games moving away from it.
-As mentioned in the pros the leveling system needs to be worked on ,but I'm sure it will be (or at least can be since it's still an EA game).
- Game will need more things to craft in the long run which includes armors/weapons.
- Not being able to be on different maps while in multiplayer needs to be addressed as well
In conclusion the game does show great promise if you're looking for a fantasy based voxel game ,but being Early Access ,and  only recently coming  out on steam  time will tell if it gets the treatment it needs.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I had the choice of spending my $20 on either the new BreakPoint pokemon cards (they look so cool ;-;) or a Steam card. I decided to get a Steam card and get this game.


This game is easily becoming one of my favorite games of all time. A definite 11 on my top 10, maybe higher.
Honestly, I loved Cube World in its time and always wanted them to keep working on it. It could've been amazing. The same can go for this game. Now, I'm not saying this game had no work put in to it, but with perserverance and some candy, this game can be great.
There are a lot of small negatives and nitpicks I have of this game, and while it certainly isn't the best game, it has its charms.

Pros Beautiful graphics and menus.
Amazing soundtrack.
Easy to start, yet keeps challenging later in the game.
Easy to navigate menus, with hotkeys even shown on each tab for quick access.
Adorable characters with plenty of options in terms of hair, ears, classes, etc.
Simple building system, just hold what block you want in your hand and left click where you want to place it.
Lots of levels and worlds with vast ecosystems and creatures.Cons Definetly NOT for low-end PCs. My old Toshiba could barely stay at 20 fps with lowest settings.
Only 2 or 3 tracks from what I've heard so far.
If you grind at lower levels, the game gets extremely easy once you get around level 10-15.
Very confusing armor equip system if you don't know how it works at first.
Nothing wrong with the character creation. NO STEAM CLOUD SUPPORT.
Like I said, simple. Could do with some complexity?
A lot of worlds are repeated levels with near the same enemies, just tougher. Not a big problem though, at least to me.RequestsI would loove a bigger skill tree and more classes, maybe jobs and special upgraded classes? I adore rpg systems is these types of games.
PETS. PLEASE. I would love to ride on one of those sand shells or fly on an eyeball.
Class-specific weapons and items. While there are buffs for your classes' main weapon, and I like that system, it could do with class-specific doodads. I'm thinking katanas and dual weilding knifes, elemental staffs (like thunder, ice, fire), shotguns or super crossbows, etc.
More ways to customize your character, hats, body types, etc.
Steam Cloud support. I played for almost 4 hours on a desktop and expected to go back to my laptop and be able to continue where I left off. Sadly, I had to start over because of no Cloud support. Terraria added it with eventual updates, so I'm expecting this to as well.

Well, that's all folks, thanks for reading my review~
:)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Looking for a helpful review look no further. This game is fun, has minor bugs but they can be over come with some patience. The worst bug I found while playing was the fact that my character would continue to run forward after I had stopped holding down the W key, which then led to me running through a mountain into a dungeon surrounded by Fallen Squires. Exciting. But for all these fun mishaps that happen there is only one major flaw in this game I think. That is the fact that it takes 20 gold ore to make one bar when it takes 10 for iron and like 5 or something for copper. 20 ore is ridiculous . It takes about 20 minutes lets say, to find enough ore for one bar. You searched the map found a big deposit, it had like 23 nice start right well now your running looking for more, wait a minute you cant find any. Well you start fighting a mirror golem and bam you see a couple of gold ore in the ground. You kill the golem and run over there to get that gold. You mine the top 3 and realize thats it. Unless you are ready to mine out the entire world I recommend getting one character. So the classes are Mage, Ranger, and Warrior. They are pretty self explanatory and all have special talents and uses. The system for leveling is quite easy to understand and amazing to say the least. While playing the game you collect portal shards to travel the worlds (great idea on the game devs parts). With new worlds comes harder foes, cooler castles, better portal shards, and most of all resources. Also multiplayer is only on LAN servers. I hope that gets changed to online. Also if the developers could make a trade system like a world market where players can sell items for coins that would make a great twist and allow them to forever change the world of portal knights. :D

10/10 would review again!!!!!!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is everything early access is meant to be.

The game itself nails the core mechanics and runs smoothly.
It's fun and doesn't feel extremely clunky.

The devs have said that they would like to release major content patches every 4-6 weeks for at least 6 months.
They are listening and have addressed that things like the challenge of the game and other complaints are being addressed right now.

If you're concerned about this being another indie dev that is going to take your money and bolt, the publisher 505 Games is the publisher behind Payday 2. They have funding to finish the game and finish it right.

Right now there's around ~20-25hrs of gameplay from 1-30, assuming you discover all the islands and get end game gear. After that it's a block building and alternative character game.

Considering that most $60 AAA titles only have <10hrs of gameplay through the whole game, I would say $15 is a hell of a good deal for a fun game.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nSo far th game is great! I had some trouble getting used to the controls, as I've been used to the minecraft controls when it comes to these types of sandbox games, but after about 1,5hours I managed to get the hang of it. The start of the game goes really fast and there's not much explaining, which is pretty nice, but has its downsides; I rushed through the first 6 areas like mad. I obtained copper pretty fast and managed to get a nice base going on my home island (which is actually pretty useless. the only thing you need is a chest to dump your recourses in). After that, it took me about 6 hours to finally get a proper feeling of progression (even though I've defeated the first boss of the game), but I had the same gear for about 4 hours which felt pretty annoying as there was no iron to be found until island 12 or so. conclusion; the balancing of the game could use some work. But hey, it's still in development! I think the game has great potential and I'd love to see a multitude of difficulties in the game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So much fun. A great combination of minecraft, great visuals, easy game play, crafting, RPG and adventuring.

Note - for anyone who doesn't realise, the idea is to set up a HOME in one of the islands and set up a base, with a workstation, etc. Then teleport back and forth with resources to craft better armor and weapons.

Some people don't seem to realise that and think you keep moving forward and little else.

This is quite a deep game once you realise this.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

27 hours in and I have managed to complete the game. That is a lot of content for a early access. It's annoying in a fun way. You tend to fall off your island while farming..... a lot. The process of completing this game is as following: get to the boss level and then farm up to make better gear and upgrade your spells for the boss fight to be. Then you open new portals and make your way towards the new boss. When in front of his portal, you grind for new gear. The better the gear, the more mats. IE you need 10 iron for 1 iron bar. You need 20 gold for 1 gold bar and you need 40 titanuim for 1 tianuim bar. The game has some bugs. But it is what to expect. It lacks some content, but that is what to be expected. As far as I know the developers are keen on feedback so they can improve a lot.

The game needs a lot of polishing and following up in addition to more content. But this is as stated early access so it will come. Great potential. Great gameplay.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So, I never could get into Minecraft nor any other block-based builder for that matter. Maybe it's too much freedom for one man to handle and I'm not american?

Anyways, I played a few hours of this game over the week-end and I'm really liking it so far. Mining, scavenging and eventually building helps you to explore further worlds and kill more powerful enemies. So even if you're not builder soul, in this game, the game gives you legit reasons to do so.

These tiny worlds are also much smaller than in Minecraft so it's just easier to play around. You never feel like you're missing out on something big.

The combat is great though I guess I would have liked dodging to be a bit more responsive (won't dodge during any animation) but I'm sure the devs will fix that since it's EA. Very Zelda-ish so if you played the Zelda series of Oceanhorn on Steam, you'll be at home.

One other point which is clearly making the difference for me is the graphics are really nice. It's colorful and crisp. The environements are already pretty diverse. Portal Knights does not feel like your average Early Access game at all. I hope the devs will support their game for a while so we can get more content/packs and new customisation for our characters (a richer talent tree would be nice, and some active skills too).

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nFun game, very addicting, huge down side is the combat system. Why? it's completely dull, you lock on with no option to free aim and just spam attacks until the target is dead, there is a dodge that can't be used during attacks (may or may not be a bug) however everything is so easy there is no reason to use the dodge at all. I love the fact that resources don't respawn on realms, this gives the game a bit more of a challenge and makes it so you don't stop and stay on one world forever, you have to constantly move from world to world. Multiplayer is great so far, have not experienced any lag or random boots yet, the only issue (for my friend when we play online) if he goes into his chest (he's a wizard) he will randomly get stuck, it happens for all the crafting stations, he's unable to exit the station and the only way out of it is to either break the station or have him leave the server. Other than that the game is very fun and addicting, definately worth a try, out of a ten rating i'd give this game a 6/10.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Great game for an early access! the game designers did an amazing job with the 3d models and animations, the world is lovely and has a zelda vibe to it. Right now the crafting progression doesn't scale with the character progression and some very nice looking sets are just bypassed which is a waste, they should instead have those as endgame sets ti give players more options (haven't reached endgame yet btw, level 13 so far).

I don't know if this is a procedural generation bug but I'm stuck on three islands at the moment (around island 8,10, 11). Those islands are relatively tiny but I spent several hours trying to find the exit portal with no success. I even dug through a big part of the islands with the drill (fast digging tool) but no luck so far. I assume the portals spawned somewhere inside the blocks somehow, or perhaps I've missed a spot.

The game has great potential and I love the boss system, I really hope the dev team will keep regularly adding content and this won't be one of those early access games that barely evolve pass the alpha. It currently only has tutorial quests and then goes full sandbox mode, the only goal remaining being to unlock all the islands and get the best crafting gears; keep that in mind if that's not your style. The game has really solid foundations and would florish with added content to enhance the gameplay experience.

Would recommend in its current state, fingers crossed for the rest.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'm having a blast with the game so far. You've seen the comparisons, but being someone who has played games for 30 years of their life, the most accurate portrayal of the game would be Minecraft (crafting, building, and mining) meets Zelda: Wind Waker (combat).

I'm more than happy to support this as an early access title, because there is a ton of potential here. I feel like the one thing that this game is going to need for it to really be a hit success, is more content--larger environments, more regions to visit, etc. The gameplay is really fun at the moment, but I can see it potentially getting somewhat monotonous.

Anyway, I'm wholeheartedly on board right now!

Last of note, if you're into cheats like infinite health, max XP, etc., then I also run a YouTube series you may be interested in which differs drastically from all the other lets-players. Enjoy!

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4Jay78_XBus

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First and foremost, if you play this by yourself, you probably will get bored quickly. This game is meant to be played in a party and you should certainly do so.

And so..

Its an interesting game, really good visuals and good controls. Movement is fluid and feels great. Camera is a little wonky but works fine. Can easily get lost in the game and just spend hours doing nothing.

The building aspect of game feels off to me, I feel it needs to be refined some but I can't really say what feels off so I am no help there.

Durability on items seems on the low side to me, not by much though.

In my 3 hours of gameplay I only got to the 5th worlds, spent a good amount of time gathering items and crafting and building a house.

If you like minecraft, and you like adventure games, you'll like this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

For what it is, Portal Knights is an amazing game. Obviously, there are some bugs and glitches, but it's an Early Access game right now so that's to be expected. The worst glitches I've experienced though, weren't much worse than moderate FPS lag and world generation lag. But of course, these are things that can be fixed in time, and I'm sure they will be fixed.

Do I recommend this game? Yes, absolutely. The graphics, world, art style, and soundtrack are all gorgeous. There are a few repetetive gameplay mechanics, but again; there is bound to be much more content added in the future.

If you don't feel like waiting out the lag, bugs, and glitches, then I wouldn't suggest buying the game just yet.

Early Access Review

If you're into Mincraft with a mixture of more RPGesque qualities this is definately a game for you. The graphics are very well put together for an early access game and content is alright.

A few things I think need work howerver...

1. The Portal" at the end of the game doesn't do anything
date: I'm assuming it's for later content.\n2. The UI for the inventory is a bit annoying to work with
recommended: maybe adding a function to quick stack/sort items would help.\n3. Being able to drop an item out of your inventory
voteText: would be a helpful feature espically if you're playing with other people.\n4. In game chat would be helpful or a push-to-talk button for those who use headsets.\n5. Perhaps make an island solely for building on that doesn't have monsters
helpfulPercent: like a sandbox island.\n6. Stats seem to have very little affect in the game at all and the skill tree needs to be revamped a bit
votesHelpful: some of the skills have no real purpose for that specific class (i.e. a bonus to int for a warrior class).\n\nThese are just a few I can think of off the top of my head. That being said I believe that Portal Knights has good potential and hope to see future content in the months to come. If you're really enjoy games like this

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is awesome so far! It has beautiful music, stunning graphics, and a good base for an RPG/Sandbox style game.

I only have a few things to point out that I would like changed about it.

Contrast setting. I could not find it in the setting menu and in places like the Crimson Woods where its this red bright world, it would be nice to change the contrast.
I noticed with the camera it glitches when the character is inside a building, and switching it to first person helps. But I personally like playing it in third person POV and would like the camera to be fixed so I'm not looking at a wall instead of my character.
More customization would be nice. More hair styles would be awesome, and in the game class customization, like more with the skill tree, would be awesome. Even adding in a sub class feature could be cool.
More inventory space would be nice. Or even a bigger chest starting out. Maybe giving 2 full rows would be nice.

Overall this game is turning out amazing! They are doing a great job over there. I hope to see more updates soon.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

There's something about this game that has me hooked, I'm not exactly sure what it is, but it kept me coming back all weekend.

So feedback for the devs:
Allow movement while attacking, having to stand in one spot while fighting is very limiting and it really brings you out of the game, it also makes it nearly impossible to dodge.

More detailed player faces, the rest of the game world and monsters are so detailed and unique, by contrast the PC's look very bland and boring, they need a bit of TLC.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Let me start off by addressing that even though I'm recomending this EA game it does not mean I think you should purchase it in the state it is in now unless just to show support for the project. I have not played hours of the game ,because it did not need that kind of time investment to get an idea of what shape it currently is in. Now with that out of the way  I'll put down some pros & cons.
Pros
+ Combat system is fun ,and is clearly akin to that of 3d Zelda games which given the graphical style of the game fits perfectly.
+ Classes though not need are a nice add on to this style of game ,by which I mean the whole Minecraft trend.
+ Crafting is easy to access ,and doesn't require any guides to makes items as the recipes are listed in the crafting  stations.
+The leveling system was a nice touch that when completely flushed out will add something more to the game ,and helps give a better blend of RPG & Voxel games.
Cons
- The maps are extremely small to the point that you can travel one end to the other in seconds.
- Though it doesn't make or break the game everything being blocky could hurt the game when compared to other voxel games moving away from it.
-As mentioned in the pros the leveling system needs to be worked on ,but I'm sure it will be (or at least can be since it's still an EA game).
- Game will need more things to craft in the long run which includes armors/weapons.
- Not being able to be on different maps while in multiplayer needs to be addressed as well
In conclusion the game does show great promise if you're looking for a fantasy based voxel game ,but being Early Access ,and  only recently coming  out on steam  time will tell if it gets the treatment it needs.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Not another minecraft clone, although some basic similarities are undeniable. This game plays more like a light action rpg. It has an simple but engaging combat/leveling system and a basic class system for flavor, though you can do all the things with any character you make.

Definitely worth checking out. Do not go for the typical minecraft strategy of massive base building right off the bat. You'll want to get deeper into this. Just make way stations until you get pass the first couple of bosses. You'll have access to WAY more materials that way.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Many people say that this game isn't very good because it's too easy. Now, judging by my play time (2.7 hrs when posting this), I guess I really haven't gotten a full taste of what the Portal Knights world has to offer, but either way, just because it's easy, does that really make it a bad game?

Alright, I am all for challenging games. It doesn't matter what it is, I Wanna Be The Guy or the Dark Souls series, I just like challenging games. I might break my controller now and then or mentally kill something, or scream, etc. but hey, they ARE ANNOYING AS- alright I'm really getting off topic... I have gameplay videos and seen people play it on Twitch.tv also. Even if I haven't played it too long myself, the game still has a great concept and is very enjoyable to play/watch. Do I like this game? Definitely.

People insult this game for how easy it is, but not Minecraft, and other very popular games? (In my opinion Minecraft is very easy once you have at least Iron, which can be found in about 1-30 minutes if you're really trying).

From what I've seen, most people just build houses and other things in Minecraft. Why not build in Portal Knights? They even showed people building in the video! Just have fun with some friends and build a castle!

Things like this!: http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=638882855

I know I'm pretty bad at writing reviews because I haven't written many... or any? I don't even know, but listen to me, this is how it goes:

Games that aren't like Portal Knights (Easy/not too hard games to lay back and chill or put to hard mode for a challenge)

-Minecraft
-Trove
-The Legend of Zelda
-Building games
-Games you play with friends
-Voxel games
-Crafting games

Games that aren't like Portal Knights(Medium/hard games that can sometimes make you break your controller/keyboard)

-The Dark Souls Series
-FPS games (Depends on the FPS game)
-Games with a very heavy story
-I Want To Be The Guy (Games like Megaman, Metroid)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Portal Knights caught my eye on the steam with it’s 4 player co-op, interesting graphics style (once you get past that it’s not minecraft!), and what seems like endless building possibilities. The sandbox type game at first feels like you’re playing minecraft besides the 3rd person starting view (you can change to first person which is helpful when building things and sometimes mining in tight spaces). Once you get past the recollection of minecraft days, you quickly see that it’s a different game with tons of possibilities. The game is listed as early access on steam, but it I think it’ll pick up a following and they’ll continue to add content. 34 more levels to get through so long as it keeps my attention, I hope to see more of the items (drilling seems to be fun), longer more challenging dungeons, and more biomes!

The combat system is pretty cool from what I saw, mobs don’t seem so bad, until you’re beaten down by a skeleton that all but one shots you! See me get beat down here! It seems fair though and works well with the ability to be able to build a wall between you and a foe if the tides of battle seem to change (they will) and you need a place to hide while your healing potion cool down replenishes. The idea came up when fighting the first boss that I saw (a giant worm) to build a roof over our head to prevent slime bombs from dropping down failed since you can’t build on the boss platform. I also hope to see a pvp option one day since when you upgrade the workbench and such you can mix and match items to create something other than the intended costume, like taking the +12 crit chance or the +5 move speed pants!
1st boss Worm Boss
Worm Boss

The maps might be one of my only complaints, though it might be that I’m just starting out, they seem small and almost redundant at times, oh look another world with trees, berries, cotton, and ogres or a slight variance that just didn’t seem worth to stop and chop down a new tree just because it looks different than the last biome when it still gives you the same wood as any other tree… When it comes time to go back to your home base which is inconveniently on another map that you have to travel to (at least there’s a quick travel system with a “home” button for quicker returns) you still must load the map, maybe a better way to quickly travel to the area where you create your crafting area and chests for overflow items can be added in the future with some restrictions that don’t allow you outside of the surrounding area that you’ve made a home/base.

See some screen shots / gameplay & review at my site:

http://liquidgamingsector.com/2016/02/29/portal-knights/

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is awesome.
Wanna kill things? Wanna be adorable? Wanna connect worlds?
All that and more with this cute, and very easy game.
If you like to run through and just own your enemies (recommended for the mage or archer class), this game is for you.
If you require a bit more of a challenge, then this game isn't really for you (unless you just want to use your default weapons, Or the warrior class.).

-Started playing game
-collected a fuq ton of ores and gems and shtuff.
-built fortress for my shtuff
-crafted epic clothes and weapons
-enemies got on house
-killed enemies and destroyed house

10/10 would have to rebuild house after battle again

BUT they need to fix a lot of bugs still, and they need to balance the costs of iron/gold bars.
20 GOLD ORES FOR 1 GOLD BAR ARE YOU KIDDING ME?!
Trying to join in on friends is still kind of crappy, and while the world is loading, you can hear the other side, like the connection turns on their microphone (your side, too) and it's really weird.
If you can even join in that is, most times it says Host has left the game" and kicks all players out.
That has to change
date: but they're still working on it
recommended: and as far as it's gotten
hoursPlayed:
I know they will complete the game nicely.
I hope they will see how unfortunate and difficult just getting enough resources to get what needs to be done will be.

All and all

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Early Access - v.0.2.2:

Game is great so far, no bugs so far, the only crash I encountered is because of my weak CPU processing output.

Crafting:
I wish there are two sides to the window, instead of one awkard window hanging on one side of the window frame. (e.g. option to flip item vertically/horizontally)

Monsters:
I wish when the knights that disappear when day time hits, could revert back to the regular monsters that were converted initially, so I wouldn't have to wait 5 minutes+ running around the map, waiting for everything to respawn.

Keep up the good work! I love the atmosphere of the game's graphics when the sun is setting and makes the treeline glow gently, as well as small details like cindering ash rising from a hot plane. I also enjoy the flexiblity that armor are not restricted to class and skills are swappable, so that I can swap around builds however and whenever I like.

Good job!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Keeping it short for now, but this is the most complete, engaging Early Access experience I`ve ever had. There is so much in it already, and it works well. It is fun, beautiful and expertly crafted. Progression is done in strides, welcoming the player to immerse in its world instead of just going for the top tier builds all at once.

I appreciate this game more than Minecraft -- the easy comparison -- as there is a clear goal and progression, giving it more meaning to the world the developers constructed. Give it a try. Hopefully this early success means the game will be even greater in the future!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is pretty much RPG meets Sandbox meets Wind Waker Art Style. In other words: The Perfect Game
I'm going to try to make this review short but as effective as possible.

I am keeping in mind that the game is Early Access, so that there will be some bugs. I'll be updating the review as updates roll out, so what you read should be the most updated information:

PROS:
- Wind Waker art Style (Very bright and full of life)
- Well mixed Sandbox meets RPG"
- Easy to learn gameplay mechanics
- Tons of Realms (Univereses
recommended: or whatever the ♥♥♥♥ you want to call it) to explore\n- Fun battle system\n- Enemies have patterns
hoursPlayed:
which pushes you to learn what they do and how to beat them\n- BEAUTIFUL Lighting
- Sp00ky night music

CONS:
- Dodging rarely works during battle
- Crafting system sometimes gives you random items (eg. Crafting a Refined Wood Block and getting a Stone Pickaxe)
- Crafting system has unessary steps for getting the items you made
- Games FPS drops slightly at night

CONCLUSION:
The game is a masterpiece

reviewText:
Early Access Review

My friend and I got this together on sale. We're both fans of games like Minecraft, but Portal Knights takes the concept a step further with a more in-depth RPG aspect.

PROS -

Unlike Minecrack, there are several worlds to travel to a fro. Although they're much smaller than a single server in MC, they're still plenty big enough to encourage exploration, and I believe the worlds' smaller sizes makes the game run smoother (whereas MC takes a beast of a PC to run smoothly).

You can build whatever you want! I've built a modest home where I farm resources, while my friend make his wizard tower up the hill from me where he makes spells and bombs.

The graphics are a bit cartoony and childish, but they're VERY pretty and leagues better to look at than MC. There are many different looking enemies and tilesets between worlds, making no place feel the same as you leap between portals.

Although there is a bit of an RPG feel to MC, Portal Knights takes it much further by making far more types of weapons and armors that add varying bonuses to suit your play style. Combat is simple, but it's more complex than MC.

There are classes! I started off as the Warrior while my friend picked the Wizard. He heals and does elemental damage from a distance while I charge in and agro. You can't do that in MC!

The game starts up very quickly and the loads screens between worlds are brief. I'm never tapping my fingers waiting to play.

CONS -

We're unsure of why it happens, but when my friend in connected to my world he crashes out of the game from time to time. While I continue playing just fine, he has to restart the game (which isn't that bad, more of a mild annoyance considering how fast the game starts up).

MC has a survival feel to it, having to cook and eat food - I wish this game implented something like that down the line. It'd be interesting to travel between worlds and eventually need to set up camp with your friend to eat some grub.

Water. There are no bodies of water, which means there are no boats, underwater creatures, or swimming. Unless there is a level down the line I've yet to see, I'd like some form of seafaring adventure.

OVERALL -

This game is awesome and I'll be playing it for a long, long time. I can't wait to see where the devs take this title and it's totally worth the asking the price. Aside from my friend crashing sometimes while we play together, I have come across ZERO bugs. For an early access game, I am very surprised and pleased with my purchase and play time.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'd buy this again any day and heartily recommend it.

Pro: Whimsical and fun coop play that's already very polished! Building and crafting is great but the game shines and sets itself apart because of level-based progression; this is not (another) open ended, open world sandbox but much more a linear Adventure with some base building and gear upgrading in between. Dungeons, special events and boss fights add variety and extra fun. Very refreshing genre mix overall, beautiful graphics and soundtrack!

Con: Combat camera needs work and can get very frustrating due to auto-lock mechanic à la Zelda. This is especially a problem in coop. Inventory management also needs to get simpler. Otherwise, in the long term it would be fun to see more modes added to the game, such as proper survival or permadeath.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Nearly 20 hours in - this is a wonderful game to play with some beautiful and colourful graphics, lots of worlds to explore and one that I'll add is a BLAST to play with your kids!

I love how I can build houses and craft items, much like that other infamous sandbox game, and thus I can sit there with a bit of a battle here or there but otherwise build my home. Is it Alpha, sure, it is! I'm looking forward to beds and the furniture I craft having a greater purpose, but it's all done in such a wonderful colour palette, I can sit back and admire my home.

I can go out and choose to adventure, different difficulty levels depending on your character's gear and the world you visit when you portal to other lands. The combat is fun and the enemies have different techniques that you can use to take them out, you can go all tank, ranged or magic on them and the visual effects are great. Boss fights are fun and can be very challenging depending on your gear, and there are lots of other innovations here like drills, resource finding tools, that can remove the grind of resource gathering (ores, gems).

I am enjoying this in both single player and multi-player (with my kids) for ANY parents reading my review, just buy it and have fun with your kids, it's a real blast, I'd say completely fine for 8 years and up (just because crafting does require a bit of thinking of what resources to gather, etc.) Characters look great, not too gory, lots of replay value here (just keep creating new worlds).  You can spawn on each other's worlds as long as you are all connected via Steam.

I enjoy playing the game on my own as well, and can happily spend an hour or two adventuring and playing, just having fun.

Does it need anything / my wishlist?

Resource stack splitting - this is something that would be great to see in a future update.
Medium and Large worlds - performance is great on the current small" worlds
date: I use quotes because once you start mining and exploring
recommended: some are quite a decent size

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So i think that by now i have spent enough time to honestly say that this is a pretty good game. Take this with a grain of salt though. My system is overkill for this game or it should be with msaa on 8x what the game automatically set me at it was using 68% of a single card no sli, now this is not much concern as when i cut msaa down it gets more reasonable with very little difference in overall quality. game looks good nice color variation and good mechanics with low impact on the cpu this is a great laptop title. One gripe is that theres not much of a tutorial at the moment it teaches you the basics but fails to teach you anything about more advanced things like farming which takes way too long and doesnt yeild much of a reward, to that extent materials are frustrating and i get it the game is supposed to get tougher as you move on. But when you reach endgame items like titanium it becomes so scarce that i had to create multiple universes in order for me and 2 friends to get geared up, albeit end game items so heres some quick notes

Story: interesting but not apparant, i would like to see more.

gameplay: fun light and easy to master good for a little bit of fun now and then. the dungeon exploring is a bit frustrating sometimes

mechanics: simple and easy to figure out if you pay attention

Optimization: Im a bit of a hardware nut so heres some specs as to compare your system to( all results are the maximums i saw when playing online with 2 other people and me hosting)
CPU: Intel I7 5930k @ 4.4ghz
RAM: 32gb ddr4 @2400mhz
GPU: 2X Nvidia GTX 970's (note sli not supported as of this review)
SSD: Samsung 850 PRO 512

so my results using this hardware with settings maxxed all the way out at a resolution of 2560x1080 60 FPS
CPU load: 15% avg of 12%
GPU load: 68% avg of mid 50's (8x MSAA)
RAM: max of 2.1gb avg of 1.7gb

TLDR: game is fun for a while, easy to master and takes some but little thought to play. Gets very grindey toward the end, easy to run and smooth multiplayer. tutorial could be better and a few more levels added just for resource sake.

overall review is good but could still use some work. grab it if it sparks you interest.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Good game
I can see many potentials from it.
However, there are a few things that I hope to be covered in the future updates.

1:Obviously lacking mutiplayer mode.
There's no offcial server running at this game.
I think it's not within the company's budget cuz the game only costs 10 bucks.

2:a few add-on/change on the mutiplayer mode
I am hoping for an open-world(endless and borderless) map for the mutiplayers.
Why?   Let's say you and your friend.
You are looking for battles, leveling up and doing quests more like a royal knight.
Your friend is passionate or more interested in crafting.
When you and your friend are in the same, it's gonna be akward.
Rather than doing the main quest, you end up staying with your friend on a low-level map
cuz all the crafting tools are there.
Moreover, when you guys try to craft, you two may end up splitting since u two are in different classes.
He needs to craft his leggings, u need your armors.
The materials are not often on the same map, so its either you find your stuff first or he first.
Everytime you have to load the map and it takes time to find the mats.

I suggest that do a borderless map for the mutiplayer mode like minecraft, or do something like cross-map
when you are playing mutiplayer.
For example: you and your friends set your base in lvl1. when you leave finding materials or doing quest in other map,
your friends can stay in lvl1. He can have the option to choose whether to come or stay which is accept the teleport or decline.

Anyway, great game. I still strongly recommend doing a borderless map for mutiplayer mode and I would like to meet random people throughout my gameplay. Just like borderlands but with borderless

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Not much I can say that hasn't been said before. I felt I got my money's worth, but just barely. I'm probably more neutral on the game.

Pros
- Early game is pretty fun.
- Graphics are very nice and most of the environments are amazing (space stuff didn't do much for me though).
- No penalty for dying, which I know is controversial, but I tend to play conservatively if there are penalties which make things even more of a grind and less fun.
- Moving between the different themes was a nice suprise.

Cons
- Inventory is limited. There are so many things you are forced to collect, but almost no room for them. Chests are small as well.
- Game is likely to go free to pay (ex. timers on crafting which have no real purpose and devs have said there will not be mod support), so just know that going in.
- No story, so no real reason to explore anything once you find just one of the portals (if not dead end). I assume they are trying to be vague like minecraft to let people create their own story, but there is so much potential for making things interesting with one (all those abandoned castles).
- Unlike an RPG, you never really find an item other than crafting materials, so you have to build pretty much everything.
- Monsters are interesting starting out, but by halfway through there is nothing new. Just recoloring and resizing of existing monters (except for the one that is nearly impossible to kill for good - so annoying).
- Monster respawn in locations that are cleared (which is generally a good thing), but it means they will respawn in a build you created or tried to turn into a home. That can get annoying and makes building things less desireable.
- As far as I know you can't use" items like new recipes without getting out of the inventory so you have to go back in a rearrange again. The new recipes were really confusing to figure out what to do with until I tried to use them in the quickbar once.
- Can't see the upgrade requirements of the various forges
recommended: etc without specifically clicking on them. So when I'm grinding for the blocks I have to remember how many of something I needed.\n- Can't put things on the ground
hoursPlayed:
just delete. Makes juggling with the limited inventory difficult.
- Combat camera is kind of annoying. Been many a time where I didn't notice I was locked in and couldn't jump to back away in time. I'm really not sure what the advantage of the roll is versus just moving out of the way.
- I'm not sure why the day and night monsters rotate. I guess it is to bring in the monsters with glow effects but just feels very wierd to me. Especially since the night monsters are pretty much all the same from the beginning of the game (colors are different is about it).
- Monster AI is pretty weak. Stand on a post 2 blocks high and almost nothing will hit you and they just stand right below you."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Amazing! If you like mining and fighting then this is your game! Spend 10 hours mining blocks to build a awesome house? Go ahead! spend 10 hours fighing monsters non stop? Go ahead! The freedom is there and you can do whatever you feel like! Grow a garden? Okay! Dig as far down as you can till you fall out the world? You can do that too! I love this game, It's like minecraft but cuter, and with more purpose and leveling! The only downside, Storage, My house is full of chests which can only hold 12 stacks of items each (Unless you upgrade them) The stacks aren't very large either, I'm forever returning home to build a new chest just to store all my new loot! I want to see better stacks and larger storage chests! but apart from that I'd rate this game about 9/10!

So far, so solid!  A really interesting little game.  Far enough away from Minecraft and it's other clones to give it a unique feel with both mechanics and graphics, it's keeping me wanting to come back to it.

So far I've only played a mage, so I don't know what the experience would be like on the other classes.

If you enjoy similar games, it's definitely worth the asking price.  If you aren't sure about it, just wait a few months.  Games in this genre hit REALLY low prices during steam sales :)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A Well made, challnging RPG set across a variety of levels. To progress you defeat monsters which in turn drop you shards. You craft these shards into portal pieces and fill in the randomly placed portal.

COMBAT: The combat is fun but a little bit button mashy and if you have lag it's impossible to dodge.

CONTROLS: The controls feel fluent and they're easy to remember.

GRAPHICS: This game has this very cartoonish vibe which is very appealing.

CONCLUSION: 9/10 not too well optimized but a fun game nevertheless.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Good game, needs more work but that is what early access is.

Pros:
-Graphics are wonderful
-Music is nice (granted repetitive, ended up just turning it off)
-Animations are well designed (although if you use an item then switch to a weapon fast enough it will continue that animation but do the weapon's ability)
-Hardly any bugs (or I'm that lucky)
-Progression is obvious

Neutral:
-Combat locks your ability to jump by replacing your jump button with a dodge, which sometimes refuses to go up 1 block (the heigh you can walk up). One can, however, exit combat mode by right clicking, giving the ability to jump freely. Annoying that dodge isnt another button, but atleast they made a workaround.
-Combat can become bland at times. It is just like Pokemon or any game with a 'weak to ___' feature. Once you learn how to exploit a creature's weakness it makes combat predictable and fast. Good for grinding, but I like a challenge.
-World isn't exactly randomly generated." Not sure if it is suppose to be but there are plenty of islands to explore.
-Multiple islands almost discourage sandbox building. Because there are so many islands to discover you almost don't want to build until you search them all
date: but you can freely change your Home Island at any time so no restrictions on that.\n-Classes in a creative sandbox game. This isn't so big of an issue as I am making it sound but character classes are rather linier with you being able to choose a 'this-or-that' every other 5 levels for a skill. Stats are also automatically placed so one can't experiment. And everyone can equip anything
recommended: so classes only restrict stats and skills.\n-Boss battles are dull and predictable. When I faced the first boss I felt a sense of excitement and fear thinking 'what if I can't defeat it' the entire time. It however played like any classic game where it has a weakness and almost presents it on a silver platter. Oh man are they pretty to look at
hoursPlayed:
great colors and animation to boot.

Cons:
-Lack of content (obvious early access con so don't take it at face value
voteText:
just letting you know whats up.)
-No server list or Steamworks.
-Up to 4 player co-op. (maybe obvious set up for a console release so I get afraid of them abandoning PC once tested)
-Game is set up for quests but so far nothing past tutorial short of 'take on all the bosses and discover all the islands.'
-No penalty for dying (yet). Not a big deal but I like to know there will be consequences for failing.
-All Item's share the same cooldown. (Hp Potions
helpfulPercent: Mana Potions
votesHelpful: Sharpening Stone [repairs a weapon's durability btw])\n-No cosmetic slot. Again not a big deal but I love the looks of certain items while I hate the ones with good stats.\n-Creative character customization

votesFunny: I don't know. I try to stay as true to myself as possible to make it an extension of me [ego])\n-No point in crafting any tools other than copper
commentsCount:
they all mine at the same rate. Havn't tested any other tool since there is no restriction for mining the highest tier with a copper pickaxe.


When it all boils down this game is really great

column17:
and maybe it'll be my alltime favorite sandbox. Until then I hope the developers do things right and with the community at large.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I don't normally play early access releases for what are probably common reasons many people don't.  I enjoy being able to bite into a finished product with relaxed escapism for hours. After being introduced to Minecraft years ago by a lifelong friend, I've played that sandbox until my eyes bled and have been looking for a refreshing spin on that idea for almost as long. I can't even touch Minecraft anymore in the same way I can't touch Skyrim, it's a want of nostalgia that remains as a crater in my gaming soul. Then came along an ad for Portal Knights on a mainstream gaming site and in spite of my better judgement, because I hate ads, I clicked it and was immediately impressed by the charming visuals, the potential in its combat, and the simplicity of its cubic world and crafting system that too many Minecraft" clones often convolute.

Now that I have the game I can't recommend it enough. It is an extremely polished opening act for a game that is literally just ♥♥♥♥♥ing started. Portal Knights nails its first set of features with a surprising level of polish. The game sets out to deliver to its audience accessible gameplay concepts along with a very handy
date: but not intrusive tutorial. As opposed to many games of this genre that drop players into its realm with no information
recommended: Portal Knights begins with a non-mandatory tutorial. So if you'd like to take a moment to know the basics
hoursPlayed: it lays out everything for you
voteText: while if you prefer to set out and learn along the way you can do that as well.\n\nCrafting is simple with a unique
helpfulPercent: RPG styled user interface. The music is reminiscent of the original entry of Fable
votesHelpful: and the art is just as nostalgic to my eyes. Portal Knight's combat feels like a return to the "Z-Targeting" era of the Legend of Zelda franchise and the interface for this combat system pays direct tribute to that legacy with an HP system managed by "hearts" and a magic system by a mana bar. It expands on its RPG inspired concepts also by allowing players to level up
votesTotal: incease their stats
votesFunny: and develope their characters along a skill tree as they so choose.\n\nExploring happens by traveling through
commentsCount: well
column16: portals as opposed to wandering through an endless wilderness - but with good reasons. By creating a world of islands
column17: the developers of Portal Knights have created a world that they can easily expand upon without forcing players to explore obscenely long distances through "old version" terrain before they experience new content in coming updates.\n\nIn short
column18: by using islands players will sooner encounter new content than by using one massive
column19: solid landmass for exploration - which is a fantastic approach.\n\nAs of this writing
column20: I am extremely excited for Portal Knights future. The game is extremely polished
column21: but be warned - it is a proof of concept. It has all it needs to be a functional
column22: enjoyable game but its limited in its current roster of things that players can do before they have done everything. If you're like me and want an early start on what could be the next crafting phenomenon
column23: then jump in to a portal near you."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

For a TLDR; look here. If not, ignore the next paragraph.

Portal Knights has a few flaws and an insane amount of potenital. I have racked up about 20 hours within a few days. Its very fun to play either in single player or multiplayer and each level offers a unique twist on the voxel based landscape. I would give it 7.5/10

Now for a more intricate and indepth review.

I bought portal knights on steam when it was on sale for $11.99. It looked like a fun alternative to minecraft and cubeworld and so I was naturally excited. With that being said, I would like to praise the game on some things while also pointing out some very serious flaws with others. I will be dividing each section down by talking about the Gameplay, Combat, Environment, and what I hope to expect.

Gameplay 7/10The only thing really keeping me from giving this game a lower score is the actual gameplay aspect. I love that I can destroy or even build onto islands and there is no one to stop me. Every Island is randomly generated which provides an amazing and unique experience every playthrough. Dungeons don't seem to be randomly generated though which could be seen as a problem by some. Characters are fun and easy to play as and allow you screw around to create the funniest looking characters or most serious looking characters. I would like to see more color customization in the future though. There is also no storyline which could be good or bad depending on your stance. Personally I would enjoy more of a backstory on why players have ended up where they are instead of just the begining and how these monsters and creatures have been formed. If you are just playing for sandbox, then I would still recommend it. That being said, multiplayer can also be a pain. As of 2/29/2016, players in multiplayer will currently all teleport to the same island whenever anyone hits the next island. This is extremely annoying and this is my biggest problem with the game right now.

Pros
Fun
Ambitious
Great to play with friends
Unique
Stress relieving
Calm
Cons
Multiplayer needs some work
Combat needs work
More lore would be nice
Not enough customization
Certain classes seem useless compared to others i.e. Ranger > Wizard > Warrior
Small backpack space
Small chests
No real skill tree

Combat 5/10I will be honest, the combat system in this game could use a lot of work. Not only does your camera stay locked on the enemy you originally hit, but if you look directly at another enemy, your target will not change meaning that if I hit enemy 1 at first and then try to hit enemy 2, I wont be able to hit enemy 2 unless I change targets by pressing tab.

Pros
Unique
Challenging
Pacing is good
Cons
Clunky
Terrible targeting system
Some classes more useless than others
Melee fighters are screwed every boss fight and need a ranged weapon
What I expect to see in the futureIf the developers of the game see this review, I would want them to know this. Your game has a lot of potential and I see it being the next Cubeworld or even being bigger than that. There is a crazy amount of potential, please don't mess it up by not listening to your fans.

I hope in the future some features are modified or added such as:

Multiplayer: Allow players to teleport to individual islands without bringing the whole group with them. Allow a loot system to be added to allow players to either split the loot or at least share it so everyone gets some. ADD A TRADING SYSTEM PLEASE. I cannot stress this enough

Gameplay: Fix combat so it isn't as clunky and buff the warrior. The warrior is so weak right now and it makes me sad because I really do love him. I would like to see less clunky tools as well and a way to craft firebombs.

Islands: Add your own guild island of some sorts. This would allow players to make an island that would be there own creation and not a randomly generated one. Players should be able to change the biome as well if they have discovered it.

Customization: More... Please... Add more hair styles and colors along with classes.

All in all this is a great game and if you have some friends to play or some time to kill, I recommend you get it. overall this game gets a 7.5 out of 10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'll start with what I don't like first, the game is wayyyyy too easy, maybe add some difficulty settings for players who are looking for more challenge. Also I think that the skill tree needs to be more diverse, each class more or less feels the same to me so I would reccommend giving each class different talents and skills.
I love this game to bits, the crafting is system is great, graphics are vivid and bright. The coop is so much fun but I always believe there is always room for improvement. I know you can make a bed/bookcase/dresser and what not in the game but I would love to be able to have some use for them. (Like sleeping gives you a boost in health or attack for a limited time, somehow using bookcases to learn crafting recipes and dresser to store cosmetic items) Maybe some immersive settings for players who are looking for a bit more of a challenge like needing to eat, drink or sleep, maybe enemy invasions within your the home you make.

All of that being said, this game is great for just being release in early access, and if you are interested you should buy it to support the developers to continue making this great game even better!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So i've been playing a lot of portal knights and it is about time i write a review.

Portal knights is a great game. Trust me on this one. If you like games like terraria, minecraft and Zelda this is the game for you. Terraria and minecraft are because of the building and landscaping you can do. Also , you can craft A LOT of armor and weapons. The tutorial is easy, and really shows you a lot about the game too.

Now for the Zelda part, the combat reminds me of it. You lock on to a target, hit your target and when he comes close or channels his attack, you can dodge it. The boss battles in this game are really amazing. Huge monsters with their own moves and skills, other ways to kill them en ofcourse: LOOOOOOOOT. Yes, bosses drop stuff.

For the crafting, you will need to mine a lot of resources. Then you have to make bars out of ores by putting them in your furnace. Once you have bars you will need to combine these with other items like some sort of cloth or gems. This takes time, but if you like this style of game why not?

All together , i can really recommend you this game if you like some of the listed games. If you dont have patients, and hate mining dont torture yourself and just buy an FPS or something.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A little bit Legend of Zelda, a little bit Final Fantasy, and a whole lot of Minecraft, Portal Knights is a fun co-operative action-RPG that's pretty solid despite its Early Access status.

Pros:
+ The cartoony art style is gorgeous. It may not be hyper-realistic, but there's an astounding level of detail.
+ Drop-in, drop-out co-operative gameplay. Grab your favourite character, find a game in the matchmaker, and portal in.
+ Tons of things to craft. Whether it's a new set of armour, a new spell, or furniture for your crazy sky-mansion, there's lots to find and create.
+ Warping between the islands you've unlocked is simple and easy. The world map allows you to portal to any world you've unlocked, and has a home button to make it simpler to get back to home base.

Cons:
- While the experience has been pretty smooth for me, there are bugs to be found. It IS Early Access, after all.
- Combat is clunky. The target-lock functionality needs some work, as it seems to want to be Legend of Zelda's combat but has a ways to go.
- Inventory management is messy. Currently, organizing your stuff can be a pain.

Bottom Line:
If you love Minecraft and action-RPGs, there's a damn good chance you'll love Portal Knights. Grab it!
