reviewText:
Early Access Review

Based off of the trailer for the game I knew right away that I loved the art style, but I wasn't sure how much actual content there was to the game. Tried looking at the Wikia, but it's mostly empty, lacking even move of the basic resources that are actually in the game, so that didn't help much. I went ahead and bought the game knowing that I could get a refund if I needed to. No refund needed. Game is well worth 15 dollars! I don't feel like adding in a life story description, lengthwise, but let me tell you that my favorite aspect is that all your characters and worlds are transferable. You can have one character keep their inventory as you move between totally different save slots, or you can have one world with 5 different character saves. Due to this awesomeness, I've built my setup to where the first of five world slots is being used as my home base. I sealed up the portal and have built a really nice house, with more to come, as my home range. I offload all my gear or prepare for adventure, then I return to the title screen and go to the second world save where I tear the different game sections apart from the inside out for resources :D


Only con that bothers me at all so far is I wish you moved a little faster. I'm sorry, there's one more actually. There is no blocking function yet with melee weapons. NEEDS TO BE A BLOCKING FUNCTION...though I'm sure they'll add that.


Also, Devs, if you read this, I beg you to PLEASE add local coop! I would love to be able to play this with my friends on a couch, even if it's just with only one other person!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Not much I can say that hasn't been said before. I felt I got my money's worth, but just barely. I'm probably more neutral on the game.

Pros
- Early game is pretty fun.
- Graphics are very nice and most of the environments are amazing (space stuff didn't do much for me though).
- No penalty for dying, which I know is controversial, but I tend to play conservatively if there are penalties which make things even more of a grind and less fun.
- Moving between the different themes was a nice suprise.

Cons
- Inventory is limited. There are so many things you are forced to collect, but almost no room for them. Chests are small as well.
- Game is likely to go free to pay (ex. timers on crafting which have no real purpose and devs have said there will not be mod support), so just know that going in.
- No story, so no real reason to explore anything once you find just one of the portals (if not dead end). I assume they are trying to be vague like minecraft to let people create their own story, but there is so much potential for making things interesting with one (all those abandoned castles).
- Unlike an RPG, you never really find an item other than crafting materials, so you have to build pretty much everything.
- Monsters are interesting starting out, but by halfway through there is nothing new. Just recoloring and resizing of existing monters (except for the one that is nearly impossible to kill for good - so annoying).
- Monster respawn in locations that are cleared (which is generally a good thing), but it means they will respawn in a build you created or tried to turn into a home. That can get annoying and makes building things less desireable.
- As far as I know you can't use" items like new recipes without getting out of the inventory so you have to go back in a rearrange again. The new recipes were really confusing to figure out what to do with until I tried to use them in the quickbar once.
- Can't see the upgrade requirements of the various forges
recommended: etc without specifically clicking on them. So when I'm grinding for the blocks I have to remember how many of something I needed.\n- Can't put things on the ground
hoursPlayed:
just delete. Makes juggling with the limited inventory difficult.
- Combat camera is kind of annoying. Been many a time where I didn't notice I was locked in and couldn't jump to back away in time. I'm really not sure what the advantage of the roll is versus just moving out of the way.
- I'm not sure why the day and night monsters rotate. I guess it is to bring in the monsters with glow effects but just feels very wierd to me. Especially since the night monsters are pretty much all the same from the beginning of the game (colors are different is about it).
- Monster AI is pretty weak. Stand on a post 2 blocks high and almost nothing will hit you and they just stand right below you."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

At First playing Portal Knights I wasn't all that impressed, in fact I didn't think much of it. Small Islands, only having the ability to take on a level 30 creature, and tha game pretty much stops there.

After finishing my third hour I really started to get into the game, and I am very happy that I got it. Now it seems it has become one of my favorite games, and the graphics are top notch.

Sure there are things that need to be added, and things to be fixed but overall it's a decent game for the price. From what I have read so far the developers are dedicated toward making the game even better which is good to read.

Do I recommend the game?

Yes I do, it is one of the more original games on the market.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This review will update over time with how I feel with the game. This is just my first impressions after 6 hours of game play.

tl;dr: Its early access and its not a bad game so far, just needs a lot of tweaking in certain areas. It has a lot of potiential otherwise. Its similar to Minecraft but its got some features Minecraft doesn't have.

So, I recommend this game somewhat. I didn't get to try the newest update yet so take that into consideration when reading this.

From its presentation, you'll probably assume this is another game that copies Minecraft. You have the right to feel that way because thats how I felt looking at the trailer. However, I paid the 15 dollars to give it a solid try and I don't regret it honestly. It feels different from Minecraft. And there's a few reasons for that.

So, for my first nitpick, The first person camera needs work since you can't see your own character at all. They should at least move your weapon lower on the screen to where you can't see the handle of your sword just floating in space like you are using the force to use it. Its a nitpick and not a deal breaker. You'll probably spend a majority of the time in 3rd person mode like I do since its way better for open field walking and combat. However, there's another mechanic of the game where you will be using the first person mode of this game.

And that mechanic is mining. Yes, this game, just like Minecraft, has mining. Its more bare bones and not incredible deep from what I saw so far.

However, the combat is pretty good actually, though basic. You can dodge, swing a sword or axe around (my style), use magic (never done it), use a bow and arrow, or jump off a cliff leading to nothingness trying to look like a bad ♥♥♥. Its good, basic, but good.

Reason there's nothingness is because the game's story is where someone separated the world into little floating islands and the only way to access said islands is through portals you have to create. Instead of heading to the Nether, you are accessing more of the world. You'll get portal shards from fighting enemies and you use them to craft portal cubes. Its usually 2 shards per portal cube. Yes crafting is in this game and its different from Minecraft. That'll be for later.

My main reasoning for only sorta recommending this game is because the islands are way, way, way, way too small. You can get bored very fast spending a half hour on one island at a time. Its so damn small and they need to be bigger. You can climb a big hill and see the whole island easily. It doesn't require much draw distance to see it all. Oh and there's RPG elements to this game so each island is focused on a specific level. They won't restrict you and make you stay on a island the same level as you but its just a recommendation.

The main difference of this game from Minecraft is the combat and the RPG elements. Now, the RPG element in this game....its underwhelming. Big time. You don't quite feel you are dramatically improving and it can take a while to go from one level to the next after level 5. This needs to get tweeked because its so unsatisfying to grind for hours only to get a slight bump in strength, endurance, or magic (you get the choice to improve on whichever one at least). There are perks but only on certain levels and I haven't seen any after level 2 or 3. Relating to this, there's three classes. Person who uses melee weapons, person who uses magic, or person who uses ranged weapons (they have names, but I don't exactly remember them). This affects how you level up and how you craft since you can craft armor and weapons.

The crafting, yes there's crafting and its surprisingly deep crafting too. You have to use different types of work stations to craft different things. An anvil will help you craft items made out of metals and stuff. A forge can make those materials you mined into ignots. A Workstation does most of the crafting, its for building lighter armor, building materials for houses, fences, misc items, etc... And the difference here from Minecraft here is that if you want to craft more stuff, you have upgrade these work stations using materials you've gathered. Its fairly basic upgrading it but it makes it feel different from Minecraft's crafting which is basic compared to this. Still both are pretty heavy in this department.

I haven't gotten to fight a boss battle yet, I heard they exist but I haven't encountered one yet.

If you're waiting for Dragon Quest Builders to be localized to the West like I am, sure, give this game a try. Just don't expect to have deep exploration. There is occaisional small dungeons to go through but they are really small for the most part. Not to mention there's been no friendly NPC's that I've encountered yet which makes the game feel quite empty. Now, there could be some and I just hadn't seen them yet, but as far as I can tell so far, none found.

I will update this when I see some significant changes or features that I've yet to explore.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI know I haven't logged that many hours with this game, but currently I'm having a lot of fun with it. I've always been the person that was never satisfied with vanilla mincraft and was constantly trying to turn it into a sandbox fantasy rpg-esque game with mods. I feel like this game fills that void! It's decently optimized for my computer, it's fun to play with a friend, biomes are small islands so I don't have to worry about a chunk cache, and it has the fantasy rpg element I was searching for without the need to install 20+ mods. Like I said, I haven't logged that many hours so....I haven't come across any problems like depletion of resources" on islands

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Review as of 2-29-16

This game has a Very high potential, it's already a great game in early access. It's almost like a 3D Terraria, or minecraft 2.0...

PROS:
+Sandbox building - find blocks, trees, plants, and special furnishings to build your home

+Furniture - find and/or create beds, chests, chairs, and so much more to decorate your home with

+Upgradeable crafting systems - upgrade your crafting bench, altar, anvil, and furnace to create, learn, and smelt more items!

+Armor does NOT degrade meaning you keep it untill you change it, (Weapons and items do degrade though)

+Class versatility - Even though you choose a class does not mean you have to use its weapons, classes only give you boosts with certain items, but you can use any weapon/armor with any class

+Leveling system/tree - 30 Level's with tree specs, and 3 different stats (so far); you don't choose one stat to continue to level up, when you level up you click the plus above stats, and it upgrades all 3, to a total of 100 (base) and can be upgraded further with your class tree, which can be changet at anytime (for right now)

+Character Customization - There's not a lot, but it's better than nothing and so far pretty good

+Bosses and Leveled areas - IDK if it's random or fixed but my world/universe has 44 islands to explore with about 3-5+ bosses, and each area is an average level set.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

CONS:

-NO quests after the starter island (as of right now)

-Combat lock can get annoying for some (Camera will lock on to target when attacking)

-Backpack and chests have little to very little room (but realistic)

-.....(so far that's all I can think of)

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

NEUTRALITIES: Some people can find the following as both pro and con.

*Leveling system

*RPG System

*(I'm sure theres more but I can't think of them right now)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I think this game is a lot more polished than most of the other Early Access titles. If you plan on buying the game, you might as well try it out now (and go through the refund policy if it turns out you don't like it). The graphics are well-done, especially for a game of this genre. I was expecting a more fluid framerate from my system (i7-4710HQ, GTX 860M, 8GB RAM --> 40FPS 1080p max) seeing as how it's the laptop equivalent, or even better (in some cases) than the recommended desktop specs. Nevertheless, at 40FPS, it is still perfectly playable. There are no dips on my end. The gameplay is alright. If you like Trove, then this feels a lot like it and I'd recommend it. If, however, you were expecting something more along the lines of Minecraft, then do not purchase this game. It is RPG first, sandbox second. The combat feels simplistic, but reminds me of a Zelda game. You basically choose to either attack or dodge, and this will have some consequences (not really such awful consequences, but consequences nonetheless). Some of the reviews target the exploration aspect of the game, and while they are correct in the fact that the first few levels (5-6 or so) offer hardly any exploration, the seventh level (at least on my game, seeing as how it's procedurally generated) had one of the most well-done dungeons I've ever seen. It was a several story tall dungeon/castle system that had some tough fights, epic loot, and an all-around good feel to it. The quests confused me for the first hour of gameplay. In the tutorial, they were apparent, but immediately following it, they vanished. I was wondering if I had done something wrong. I hope more quests are added soon, as well as a bit more variety to the zones, as seen in the tutorial and I believe the seventh zone. The first boss fight was interesting. I felt it was challenging, partly from the mechanics themselves (after you learn them, it's a cakewalk) and partly because of the combat system. Sometimes I felt it just wasn't responsive enough. I apologize for this wall of text, I'm rather bad at formatting reviews.

TL;DR
I see a lot of potential in this game. As long as the devs continue to support it, I'll continue to recommend it. Buy if you want a fresh, unguided RPG with some exploration aspects. Don't buy if you are looking for a Minecraft clone.

Thanks for reading :)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Gameplay/Review Video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=E-pMPj5UqT0

TL;DR: Definitely worth a buy, however a few frustrating bugs for 144hz monitor users as of now.

Pros:

+Nice Graphics
+Simple Controls/UI
+Fluid Gameplay
+Lots of adventure/exploration
+Good RPG Features
+Good Crafting System
+Boss fights
+Lots of different enemy types (However more than a few are just variations of the same enemy)
+Cool cinematic style combat

Cons:

-Multiple bugs for 144hz users
-Not much of an incentive to build
-Some areas are very short
-Lots of enemies are simple varations of eachother (Not a big con)
-No sprint (Slow movement)
-Not A lot of Different Content
-Bad AI (Always gets stuck etc.)

8/10 Great game, but needs some additional bug fixes and maybe some more content updates.

Early Access Review: For early access this is a well polished and designed game which I find fun and very charming. I've had no crashes or slow downs in first 30 hours but I have avoided coop where the few problems probably exist. Its worth the buy, they could release this in a patch or two if they wanted and call it complete but I'm hoping they expand on it and the community grows.

There are dozens of craftable weapons and 75 armor pieces or around 20 sets.  The armors come with bonuses, you can mix and match.There are several simple scripted bosses , those bosses drop some recipes and other items. Different biomes, enough block and crops variety gives this sandbox builders a great headstart.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I think this game is a lot more polished than most of the other Early Access titles. If you plan on buying the game, you might as well try it out now (and go through the refund policy if it turns out you don't like it). The graphics are well-done, especially for a game of this genre. I was expecting a more fluid framerate from my system (i7-4710HQ, GTX 860M, 8GB RAM --> 40FPS 1080p max) seeing as how it's the laptop equivalent, or even better (in some cases) than the recommended desktop specs. Nevertheless, at 40FPS, it is still perfectly playable. There are no dips on my end. The gameplay is alright. If you like Trove, then this feels a lot like it and I'd recommend it. If, however, you were expecting something more along the lines of Minecraft, then do not purchase this game. It is RPG first, sandbox second. The combat feels simplistic, but reminds me of a Zelda game. You basically choose to either attack or dodge, and this will have some consequences (not really such awful consequences, but consequences nonetheless). Some of the reviews target the exploration aspect of the game, and while they are correct in the fact that the first few levels (5-6 or so) offer hardly any exploration, the seventh level (at least on my game, seeing as how it's procedurally generated) had one of the most well-done dungeons I've ever seen. It was a several story tall dungeon/castle system that had some tough fights, epic loot, and an all-around good feel to it. The quests confused me for the first hour of gameplay. In the tutorial, they were apparent, but immediately following it, they vanished. I was wondering if I had done something wrong. I hope more quests are added soon, as well as a bit more variety to the zones, as seen in the tutorial and I believe the seventh zone. The first boss fight was interesting. I felt it was challenging, partly from the mechanics themselves (after you learn them, it's a cakewalk) and partly because of the combat system. Sometimes I felt it just wasn't responsive enough. I apologize for this wall of text, I'm rather bad at formatting reviews.

TL;DR
I see a lot of potential in this game. As long as the devs continue to support it, I'll continue to recommend it. Buy if you want a fresh, unguided RPG with some exploration aspects. Don't buy if you are looking for a Minecraft clone.

Thanks for reading :)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I absolutely love this game. I never got into the whole Minecraft thing partly because of the aesthetics and partly because crafting has never been one of my favorite things. PK resolves both of these issues: the aesthetics are great, the world is beautiful, and the characters are adorable (in an improved Lego-universe-esque kind of way). Unlike Creativerse, which is a similar concept, the monsters and other critters you encounter in PK aren't ridiculous looking - they look like mosters and critters should - kind of intimidating and scary, but in a way that wouldn't make a 5 year old run away in terror. Craftng is also simple and straightforward - read the recipe, find the ingredients, then use the proper piece of equipment (workbench, forge, anvil, or altar), and boom, there ya go. Getting to the next tier of stuff requires upgrading your workbench etc, which requires materials on higher level worlds. Then the upgrades give you new recipes for higher tier weapons, armor, spells, potions, etc., which in turn require new ingredients from higher level worlds. That whole dynamic makes it almost like one of the good Civ games - you want to play just a little longer to find the portal and discover the next world, or harvest enough X so that you can finally craft that whoziwhats that you've been waiting for. The whole game feels very lovingly constructed and nicely polished for an early release.

The only downside so far is that sometimes the portals which connect the worlds are located in really obscure and hard to find locations. No, I'm not talking about the deepest levels of a dungeon that you only know exists because you can see it and access it through a grate in the floor. I'm talking about places that you can find only by jumping off the edge of the world and dying multiple times and trying to spot the entrance to a cavern way down at the bottom of the world, and then you have to try to find a way to dig down and locate it. If the portals are close enough to the surface, apparently you can hear them, but when they're that far down, at least I can't. That whole thing can be a bit frustrating.

Portal Knights is like if Minecraft, Lego Worlds, and Cube World had a baby, and it got the best features of all the parents. Chances are, if you like one or more of the above, you'll really like Portal Knights, so give some love to a great indie studio and drop the $15 on it. If the additional content they're promising is as good as this early release, it will be awesome.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

My girlfriend hates playing games. She doesn't like any game I've played with her, we're talking minecraft, saints row, borderlands 2 etc. This game is the first game she has really gotten into, it's incredible. We played it all day and we're going to play it more tomorrow! Decorating your house in this game really is fun and everything looks amazing, the weapons are super cool, too! I hope we can kill our first boss soon!

If there is any cons to be had, and keeping in mind it's early access, there was one moment where I couldn't do anything and everything became unresponsive, which may be a bug I did through the inventory by accident, and my gf's computer started randomly lagging horribly at certain points, but turning down her graphics fixed that easily. Other than that, you can't drop items yet and you can't split stacks. I'm sure this will be implemented soon though, the way you share items currently is you put it in a chest so your friend can get it.

Other than that, even as an early access game, this is definitely a minimum of 7/10 at this point, a very good buy if you like building a nice house and going out to explore different dimensions to get more items and interesting biomes whenever you want!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Basically think of it as a lite version of minecraft + trove. The combat is simplistic but more tactical than minecraft, with a simple dodge mechanic. Note that attacking freezes you in place, so you have to time your dodges and attacks, no spamming. But once you get the hang of it, it's easier to play than most games.

The building functionality is very light weight as well. Basic array of materials, with very little variety at the start. It's not Terraria, Minecraft, Starforge where you have a lot of variety of blocks early on.

Everything is strictly tiered. Not a lot of alternatives with give or take. Just straight improvement over improvement.

My recommendation is to use this as a cheap or relaxing way to get into voxel based games, but if you're looking for an advanced builder or combat game, all the other options are better in some regard.

CONS:

Overall, game has GREAT potential for the future and I would love to see what progress this game can make.

Oh and for the love of god, change that facebook advertisement quote, that '#1' makes me cringe.

Early Access Review

Great game! This game shows a SUPER promising future. The art is breathtaking, the combat system works very well, (Reminds me a bit of Ocarina of Time) and the enemies have great AI and offer somewhat of a challenge. I won't compare it to other games that might be somewhat similar, because this game is unique in it's own way.

I give it a 9/10, only because the little, tiny lack of content. However, this game is far from done according to Devs (Developers), and I trust this game to only go uphill with such great Devs, (Seriously, we could use more like them) They are very open to player ideas, and update frequently. In fact, they are planning on releasing large updates every two weeks, though never stopping updates to bug fixes. All in all, this game shows a very promising future, and I trust when its finished, it will be a beautiful game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Playing this game on Day 1 of release, you'd never have known it was early access. Portal Knights is incredibly well polished for how early it is, and it brings together a lot of great features that (for some reason) have never been properly implemented together before; Building, Mining, Crafting, Leveling, Combat, Bosses, Dodging, Dungeon Crawling; The list goes on.

As others have said (and what really got me to try the game out), Portal Knights is not another Minecraft clone. It's much more of a casual RPG set in a voxel universe. You level up, you have talents (though currently pretty minute), you have proficiencies (again, currently very basic). When you attack an enemy, you enter a sort of Combat mode, where you lock on to your target and can dodge roll, attack etc. While in the mode (as well as while not), you can actually use your hotbar as a sort of 'spellbank', and since every class can use every item, you can have a bow on 1, sword on 2, fireball on 3, heal on 4 and utilize these in larger pulls/bosses etc.

----------------------------

PROS:
The game has a lot of decorative items and nice looking blocks, tons of foliage, vegetation and a decent variety of mobs. All of which I am thoroughly excited to see grow and evolve. There are 4-5 bosses currently in the game (I've only fought two so far myself) and they have great mechanics, if only a bit too easy.

There are a lot of crafting recipes, some of which you learn by scroll drops (I love this and hope to see a lot more/more rare ones etc) and the models look fantastic and theres a ton of variety. Same goes for armor, but armor has something even more interesting to see in a game like this; Effects. Similar to set bonuses (though you dont need multiple pieces to gain the effect AFAIK) you get a sweet effect on your character just for having certain gear equipped. The effects are more specific to classes, but generally useful for everyone (Crit Chance etc). Can't wait to see this expanded.
-------------------------
CONS:
Difficulty (The game feels a bit too easy as-is)

Mob Variety (There are a decent number of different mobs, but I would love to see more)

It Ends (It appears on the map that after 40+ portals and 4-5 Bosses, there is an Ending" so-to-speak
date:
or at least a final portal after the (current) final boss.
-------------------------

Things I hope to see in this game:

-Hard/Hardcore Mode: While still very fun
recommended: I find the game very easy
hoursPlayed: even if you don't upgrade your item sets asap. Would love to see a more difficult mode that makes having a party more of a necessity\n\n-Hunger/Thirst: Currently food and vegetables are mostly used for potions
voteText: as they barely restore any health. It would be great to have a reason to farm food as it being necessary to survival.\n\n-Player Damage/Dueling: The lock-on combat style could be really fun; having to time dodges
helpfulPercent: plan combos
votesHelpful: etc. Plus
votesTotal: sometimes I just want to kill my friends.\n\n-Authorized Steam Workshop support/mode: I think what can really propel this game to a No Man's Sky/Starbound level of infinite potential would be to open Workshop portals (perhaps as a seperate mode entirely) that would be submitted
votesFunny: voted on
commentsCount: and only accepted by developers/the community (so as to not have a billion trash maps). I could see myself (and I'm sure many others) spend some serious time creating awesome worlds for other players to explore.\n\n-Class Specific Items/Skills: This one I am tossed up about. When playing with two friends (each of us a different class) it really does not matter what any of us have/use. While it is kinda cool to be able to learn mage skills or craft incredible potions as well as build and use weapons etc
column16: I do think it would be really cool to need a friend to use certain skills
column17: or craft certain things. Plus
column18: it could be fantastic to utilize mages healing as it being necessary sometimes.\n\nAll in All
column19: this game is in fantastic state
column20: especially for just hitting the market and has an immense amount of potential. Looks polished
column22: and has a ton of nice stuff bundled extremely well into a unique Voxel based universe. I really want to see this game grow and would love to help any way I can. Plus

its cheap! I got it for $11USD on sale but 14.99 is a steal.

Highly Recommend.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I will start with I enjoy playing this game. The combat is fluid, the crafting is new but I got use to it and over all a solid game for version 0.1.2. The only problem I have with the game is the crafting requirements on some recipes. Ten ore for one bar is a lot and that only the second tier of metals. The third tier of metal requires 20 ore for one bar. This means my hour or so of collecting ore gave me 4 bars. That’s not a difficulty change it’s just annoying! At ten ore a bar one hour of farming was 15 to 20 bars, that is worth it! With 15 to 20 bars you can see growth on you character; Upgrading crafting tables, new equipment, and more. The 4 bars was one crafting table leveled and nothing else. D:

Another problem was the chests, the first tier required ore that was easy to collect and only need 2 of it. That was half the cost of making a bar for the tier. The next two tiers of chest required bars not ore and it was 2 than 3 for second and third tier. Now this wouldn’t be bad if you got a lot of extra space for the resource cost but you got 4 extra slots(12 slots to 16 slots and so on)….. So here is to a lot of tier one chests!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I bought this expecting a minecraft clone and I was half right, even though it is in its infancy this game has a lot of potential as Im hoping the developers keep on working with it as these days a lot of MC clones seem to be rushed out for only to empty a few pockets then fall by the wayside.
My experience with the game so far has led me to a few niggles,

The CRAFTING:
Limited at present with a few dozen recipes but with future updates I'm sure it will become as extensive and as intensive as MC, maybe not building reactors with redstone intensive but hopefully a more entertaining craft recipe list. There are certainly more weapons than MC and most with additional bonuses to crit rates and damage.

The MOBS:
There are a few different the further you go on but mostly the same on various maps, but they look better than standards MC (without mods or graphics packs), but never the less they do suffer from some glitches such as getting stuck behind doors with you out of their reach, but not so the other way round as ytou can hit them but they cant hit you, one for the kiting and dropping them off in a pit fans, as they cant jump or climb apparently plus they simply stare at you as you slowly erode their health as they can't reach you, I almost pity them but I want their loot so I dont.

The BOSSES:
Only 3 so far but if your not ready they'll still kill you plus theres the added danger of falling off the platform if your not aware of where your stepping, frustrating when the boss is about to die after 10 minutes of dodging his attacks onlyfor you to fall of the edge of the platform. Plus the way to defeat them is pretty obvious once you know.

The WORLDS:
At times some are very dark and the torches you can carry only light a some area, even if you pop a couple of them on the ground they only lights a slightly larger area, plus when you mine the blocks either pop out of existance or sometimes delay disappearing and it can be a bit offputting when mining. Plus resources are scarce but at least the DEV's have thought of a way to find them with the diving rod.

But other than that a good game to look forward to, so please DEV'S keep at it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Great game, very polished for an Early Access, absolutely woth its money! Get it now!

A well balanced mix of exploration, building, terra-forming, decorating, levelling up, crafting and looting. A multiplayer co-op RPG in a block-builder-world. And it does that really well - and looks beautiful by the way.

PROS:
- Co-op multiplayer. You can build, fight and explore together with your friends.
- Multiple RPG classes. Fighting in a team is especially fun because you can select different character-classes with different playstyles.
- Beautiful graphics. The game looks great and is obviously done with a lot of love. I would say upper 20% of all games on Steam.
- Very polished. So far I didn't experience bugs, crahses or any other issues. Very untypical for an Early Access title. I wish more developers would take their EA releases that seriously.

CONS:
- Honestly, I couldn't find one yet. :-)

SUGGESTIONS:
- Add Steam Workshop support! That would even increase the potential of the game.
- Add key-binding support.

If you liked Minecraft, Starbound, Zeld or Terraria, go buy this game!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Basically think of it as a lite version of minecraft + trove. The combat is simplistic but more tactical than minecraft, with a simple dodge mechanic. Note that attacking freezes you in place, so you have to time your dodges and attacks, no spamming. But once you get the hang of it, it's easier to play than most games.

The building functionality is very light weight as well. Basic array of materials, with very little variety at the start. It's not Terraria, Minecraft, Starforge where you have a lot of variety of blocks early on.

Everything is strictly tiered. Not a lot of alternatives with give or take. Just straight improvement over improvement.

My recommendation is to use this as a cheap or relaxing way to get into voxel based games, but if you're looking for an advanced builder or combat game, all the other options are better in some regard.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So far I'm having fun, the building is very pleasing and the aesthetics of the game are beautiful. I do have a few issues and suggestions that I've listed below:

The combat system feels really odd, when you attack it locks you on to an enemy and replaces the jump with a dodge in all four directions. In my opinion the combat should be unlocked by default, jumping should still work, and they should add a dodge and lock-on hotkey. This is really the main issue I have with the game

Targeting some blocks to break them can be a bit annoying sometimes, probably due to the same reason the combat feels so wonky with it's auto-lock system

More quests should be added after the first level.

A gamepad UI would be a great addition, I play with a steam controller and having the buttons displayed on screen would make it much easier to use.

I will update this as I play.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is more complete than most fully released titles in its current state, and very fun if you're the type of person who enjoy Sandbox RPGS. Its fairly basic in its current iteration but there's still plenty of content to keep you busy. I still haven't reached the endgame and I'm still having quite a bit of fun, especially with friends.

Combat is a little strange since you can't jump during a fight (makes flying enemies really annoying for a melee class); but it is still quite fun. Much like in Terraria, you can choose to forego your classes traditional weapons and armor to use another class, if the stats just speak to you more, which is always a plus. Enemies have a good diversity of attacks and abilities that should keep you entertained throughout your engagements.

The class structures are on the low end in terms of diversity; abilities you get from leveling up are fairly linear and they don't change up combat too much besides giving you a bit more powerful towards your default archiatype. That's the point though, since every weapon, armor and even ability in the game can be crafted by any of the classes; its designed for you to more pick how you want to play, instead of just being chicken-holed into a certian style.

Well worth the 15 dollars; especially considering the amount of content is just going to quadruple as the game goes along.

Also Its being published by the publishers of Terraria; I imagine those publishers have good taste.

EDIT: A lot of negitive reviews seem to be nitpicking at the dimension sizes. Make no mistake, these reviews are missing the point of the game completely. Yeah every dimension is an island in terms of size; but that's the point, that's why there's over 40 of them with a boatload more on the way. Every dimension is supposed to be a small island with about 30 minutes to 60 minutes being the max amount of time you spend in one; then you hop onto the next one and continue your adventure in a whole new area.

Early Access Review

The bosses are super easy, like they want you to learn the boss mechanics like one of the old games which is awesome, except you respawn right in front of it and it doesnt reset the boss battle...thats right folks....you just respawn and keep fighting it so you can essentially ignore the boss mechanics.

the combat is massively clunky and you cant attack and move with tab targeting basis



My biggest gripe is that it has so much potential if it was in an open world setting instead of instanced little areas where each one you have to keep teleporting to for better materials for better gear

the game looks amazing

I will look at this game in a few months to see if they fixed any of everyones gripes and if they change combat ill give it a try.

Also please add an open world where you FIND portals to those little islands with a dank peice of treasure somewhere in it. Not just the little islands as the entire game



Yes only because this game has potential and hopefully they listen to feedback.


Suggestion- Make portals more rare and the worlds bigger and it will get a more adventurous feeling as well as progressive. Make the portal worlds significantly harder each time.

Early Access Review

As for inventory I can see the gripe about early on but fact is its part of character development earning and crafting the high level chest. It adds another layer of progression.

See what the small Islands provides is a more focused content development like in dungeons I have encountered many cool things. Like chest hidden behind stairs hidden rooms behind them  or look down hey through that grate on the floor I see a hidden room and some mobs.

For 15 this game is a steal most would charge you 30 take away the rpg add pvp greifing and a endless" but non unique map. reviewText:
Early Access Review

Honestly, this game is amazing. I thought it would be something I will only play for a few minutes and get bored of. I had money to spend so I decided to purchase this game and now I feel as if I can't stop playing it. This game is very fun and entertaining. It also feels like this is not an early access game (This is very important, early access games I generally look down upon). Aside from that however, there are some issues that I have within the game.

- Enemies keep spawning in places you've repaired and claimed as your home (May be fixed now, possibly a problem on my end only)

- No way of traveling over a world for faster transportation (Ex: I have a house on the other side of a section of the world and walking there feels like it takes way too long. Maybe have a minecrart or something similar to that you can ride)

- Almost all worlds are hostile (I know it's sort of the point to have hostile worlds for challenges but a home world should have a peaceful setting or something along those lines)

- Cannot sleep in beds to make day

- Game feels as if it gets somewhat repetivive (Need more world variety)

- Larger chest storage (I always run out of places to put items and the tier one chests don't feel like enough. My inventory gets fiilled up way too quickly)

Overall this is a great game and I hope to see some more fixes added in and some improvements. Keep it up!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is just to summarize as whatever I typed below is more like a Journal:

Portal Knights is like Minecraft with much, MUCH more fun Boss Fights. Mostly focussed on co-op play though so bring a friend.

Journal:
This game is good. There is a bit of lag on mine, where the character either move too fast or can't keep up with the mouse movement. I think that might be my own computer problem though.

On gameplay, good luck to those who choose warrior. It's my job and i'm drinking those hp potions like crazy! Dodging is hard on warrior, as I keep holding the attack key which spams attack and can't dodge in time. Have not tried the other 2 classes yet, but it should be easier than the warrior class since they are ranged.

This is more focus on being a multi-player game though, as the moment I went to the 2nd world and tried fighting during the night, I was mobbed like crazy. Good thing the mine was nearby so I could easily escape. Death has no penalties in the game so far which I like.

Overall, besides the mouse sensitivity and lag problems which i think might be due to my computer not the game, I enjoyed this game alot.

Update after playing awhile more:
Ok so warrior is not that weak. After I upgraded my wooden sword to copper battle axe, killing things got much, MUCH easier. With the spells added in I can survive now.

Walking around feels a bit awkward though, with the 3rd person view sometimes going wonky and the first person view not showing much at all. And during combat the first person view does not auto-aim the monsters unlike 3rd person view, and yet you can't move freely as well, always walking around the monster you have targetted.

2nd (and probably the last) Update :
I've fix my lag issues, thanks to helpful reviews in the store page. All is fine now, except that gameplay gets a bit tedious after awhile. Once you have found a trick to melee gameplay, as long as you don't get mob you'll definitely win. For flying enemies, it's a good thing we are allowed to use other weapons like the bow, because the electric bats you encounter in the early dungeons just never, ever, goes to the ground! Died to them 2x before remembering a review saying that we can use other weapons beside those for our jobs as well.

I've not fought the boss yet, but it should probably be around the same like Minecraft ones, with more action probably.

3rd Update:
I've done the first boss fight. Victory in the first try. Maybe the boss needs to be stronger? I went in there thinking it would be much harder than that. Even prepared a few regular healing potions, and made sure I got full viking armour set too. The first boss definitely can be harder than that.

4th Update:
I've found the range weapon for the warrior. And now that I've advanced further in, there's seriously a lot of weapons and armour set, and each have it's pros and cons too. Combat gets much harder the deeper you go into the game, and that heal spell saved my life plenty of times.

It would be nice if we could have multiple buffs on at the same time though, but each buff for the warrior currently only last 10seconds at most. Currently the warrior +Att Spell and +Def Spell are seperate, and since both only last for 10seconds and you can't use it together, having to choose between which to bring along makes things difficult. Maybe late game spells have a option of joining those 2 together so I can have the best of both worlds? I'm only at tier 2 upgrades after all, on iron equip so I have no idea about the late game spells.

5th Update:

I finally reach the 2nd boss fight, and damn what an adventure it was! This is not minecraft or terraria or any other game that previously came out that is similar to it. THIS IS PORTAL KNIGHTS! And the 2nd boss fight showed it. Damn it was good. And I thought it was going to be as easy as the 1st boss too! It wasn't though, the balance was just nice.

Conclusion:
This is a great game, and I would recommend you to play it. Just try to play it with a friend since it can get a bit tedious after awhile, as being alone makes it very tiring collecting items and grinding.

Currently everything in this game is about encouraging co-op play, with the heal spell upgrading to healing a partner as well, and the warrior spells being split into +Att and +Def, which means having 1 person tank while another attack is the recommended gameplay. Mobs also get much hugher HP further in, so having more people together means faster completion of the level. Finding the portals also gets harder too, so having more people helps.

I've only at most reach mid-game status though, so I hope it improves later on for those that prefer playing solo. But this game is definitely different from any other blocky game out there!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Great game for a Early access with very few bugs. So i will write some Posetives and negatatives from my point of view. (my opinions). Keep in mind its an Early access so alot will be fixed in time.
+ Easy controlls.
+ Alot of variations both biomes and mobs.
+ Alot of items to keep you busy farming.
+ Challenging. You have to dodge attacks or else you die fast.
+ Fun combat but needs some more work.
+ It's a serious development team, So hopefully we will see this Early access through.
+ Epic boss battles.
+ Not demanding in graphics , I could install this on my ♥♥♥♥♥♥ work laptop and play with good fps.

- Didnt feel fun to increase level, no new attacks or spells.
- The AI needs some work.
- Warrior is underpowered, you will just end up with useing the bow all the time anyway.
- The dungeons need some improvements. At the moment they dont offer any unique loot so wasnt drawn to them. (atleast what i have got from them)
- End game.

I've yet to play Portal Knights a lot (10 hours at this moment), but feel like writing a review of my experience so far anyway. >_<

I bought this because my brother recommended it to me, and mainly to play together with him. So far, we have played a bit in one of his worlds and I've played some in my own.
Having played games like Minecraft, Cube World and Trove a lot (and liked them, to a point), I felt that Portal Knights could be my kind of game. So far, I'm not disappointed. In PK, you first get the sense that you've been put into something like Minecraft, but with obvious RPG elements. You choose your class, so far there are the 3 basic ones (Warrior, Ranger, Mage), and then go on to customize your character (a bit limited at the moment, but as a new game, I didn't really expect that much yet) and choose a name. Pretty basic stuff for an RPG.

Then you choose a Universe(/World), from the 3 you can have at once (you can also have 5 different characters, which all share the same 3 universes), and enter it. The first Island" is a tutorial to get you into the basics of controls

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So far this game has been a blast. I have only played Single player hope to play multi soon once some friends or randoms add me to play. But really if you love leveling, grinding, crafting, smithing, bosses with challenges as how to beat it this game is for you. I have at the time of writing this review unlock 12/44 portals, Beat the first boss, and have made my first Home Building with everything I can up to this point. Give this game a try you wont reget it.

xD

ps Alot of people give this game bad rep but tbh The only words they say is crafting is bad and the grind is hard and bosses are easy... and I would say the crafting is hard with a grind due to you need alot of a item to make a item. Bosses are only easy if you out level the boss with higher end gear, like I said I beat the first boss which is level 10 with higher than level 10 items.. so Please read more reviews dont let bad reps turn you away.
I say 10/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Honestly I didn't expect to be this satisfied with an impulse buy. I bought this game because of the mix of RPG like progression, the exploration element and the charming artstyle that reminds me of minecraft, zelda and even a bit of terraria. There is not much story beyond the initial premise of establishing that you are a hero and must travel between portals to help the land and a somewhat simplistic combat mechanics is not really a bother but rather an endearing trait.

It doesn't hold your hand much nor force feeds you a story, just go out there explore the islands, gather materials and craft increasingly powerful gear and tools to fight ever more powerful enemies. The crafting is surprisingly deep already for an early access title. The game oozes both personality and potential at this early stage. If you like exploration, crafting and combat that will probably remind you at times of the Legend of Zelda: Ocarina of time then keep an eye out for this one. Imho its already worth the price and it can only get better from here.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I went into this game thinking it was gonna be a so so game. I read a few reviews and saw they said good things about it and I gotta admit; THEY WERE RIGHT!!! Minecraft, Harvest Moon, The Legend of Zelda all mixed into one!!! Bought it at 11pm loaded it up and next thing I knew it was 5 am and we were still going. The game is addictive if you love any of the before mentioned games.

We started off with questing and adventuring and then by the end of the night we were all building our home world into a massive castle for all of us to call home.

If you're into a game that has a lot of dynamics (quests, exploring, crafting, building) then you should definately look into buying this game!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Great game! This game shows a SUPER promising future. The art is breathtaking, the combat system works very well, (Reminds me a bit of Ocarina of Time) and the enemies have great AI and offer somewhat of a challenge. I won't compare it to other games that might be somewhat similar, because this game is unique in it's own way.

I give it a 9/10, only because the little, tiny lack of content. However, this game is far from done according to Devs (Developers), and I trust this game to only go uphill with such great Devs, (Seriously, we could use more like them) They are very open to player ideas, and update frequently. In fact, they are planning on releasing large updates every two weeks, though never stopping updates to bug fixes. All in all, this game shows a very promising future, and I trust when its finished, it will be a beautiful game.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nIf you liked Minecraft but thought it could use some more RPG elements (and better graphics), this is for you. There are some aspects of multiplayer that I'm not a fan of (universe is hosted on host's computer so you can only play when they're on, when one person goes to a different world the whole group goes with them, etc.) but overall this game is really fun. I can't wait until they add more to it, but even in early access the game is more than worth the $15!!
voteText: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I desperately wanted this game to be good.

Sadly after several hours of playing i have to say it has very little to offer.
the further you go in this game the bigger the grind becomes to make stuff. from these portals to even basic items like a iron pickaxe.

At first crafting seems like the standard thing. 4 copper here and 2 coal for an iron ingot. but then the next step already is 10 iron ore and 4 coal and then 20 gold ore and 6 coal!
This would not be a problem if it was not already a pain in the arsh to collect some of it. but because its so spread out and the supply is so very limited. it can take you hours to gather enough for maybe a weapon or some armor.

its so padded out that it tries to make it look like it has plenty to offer. but its so slugish and slow that before you know it your done with this already. since every isle you come across looks like a Swis cheese you dont really feel like fixing them up. are there any liquids in this game? i have only seen the acid that the first boss bathes in but besides that there has been no water to speak off.

My simple question remains. what is this game trying to be?
A minecraft clone that looks better? it sure looks better but it thats a subjective oppinion. but building a house can be done in minecraft, in every buildy buildy game and they do it better.
An adventure game? there is so much grinding to do that the only adventure there is are the boss fights.
The dungeons" are simply another cave with nothing at the end of it to reward you or make it worth the effort. a simple chest perhaps with material drops from enemies you already beated the crap out of.

Speaking of a load of crap.
The inventory gets clogged up with every random bits you encounter. like 20 diferent seeds for tree's and plants and veggies and whatnot. it would not be a problem if the inventory had more then just 32 slots. this includes the 8 hotkey action bar. in which you must have a weapon
recommended:
pickaxe and healing atleast. thankfully armor equiped does not take inventory space but there is still so little room to work with. the first chests you can make only hold 12 items. For some reason the UI and item images are FAR to freaking large. having them even a half the size would be more pleasant to look at then these "cutsie" items.

Overall i would seriouslly wait to see what this game will become. maybe its the second minecraft? but for that it would require so much more. maybe its the next Windborne and gets canceled because it has nothing to offer at the moment.

I seriously hope it is the first of the two but that remains to be seen."

Early Access Review

Great game! This game shows a SUPER promising future. The art is breathtaking, the combat system works very well, (Reminds me a bit of Ocarina of Time) and the enemies have great AI and offer somewhat of a challenge. I won't compare it to other games that might be somewhat similar, because this game is unique in it's own way.

I give it a 9/10, only because the little, tiny lack of content. However, this game is far from done according to Devs (Developers), and I trust this game to only go uphill with such great Devs, (Seriously, we could use more like them) They are very open to player ideas, and update frequently. In fact, they are planning on releasing large updates every two weeks, though never stopping updates to bug fixes. All in all, this game shows a very promising future, and I trust when its finished, it will be a beautiful game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

At this current state of the game, it's a big fat NO. Game is full of bugs, it lags often, crashes randomly, things disappear, ...

Fun in multiplayer with friends, but WAY to broken to be recommendable. Only way to play with others is to manually add them on steam. Half of the time you still can't join their game, you're either stuck in the loading screen or your screen turns black.
Furthermore there's no multiplayer servers. So the same person always has to host the game, or everything you build is gone.


Singleplayer is really boring, as the story is non existant and there's nothing really interesting to explore.


Game is insane about grinding. You hack for ours to get the ores necessary to craft something more interesting. Which is really pointless though because there is just NO reason to fight enemies!
You can just run around them, dig happily a few meters away from them or just stand a little higher on a cliff and shoot downwards, as they can't climb up.

This makes the game extremly easy and boring. Not to mention you get more experience for digging. So at the end we were just exploiting the game by blowing up the environment with the bombs, quickly leveling up 10 !!! levels in less than 20 minutes..

Even worse, combat feels clunky and unrewarding. It's only fun in the first levels, afterwards you just fight monsters because they spawn in a position where you want to build or dig something. zzzz


Really positive is the graphics and the sound though. It just looks beautiful and the different worlds are full of interesting looking plants.
The dungeons look all the same though, so once you went into one you know them all. And the maps are REALLY small.


So better safe your money and wait until it get's out of early access (or at least more patched in a few months). Perhaps the DEVs fixed all the bugs and improved the game, then it could be really cool. But right now, it's just too much of a grind and pain with all the bugs.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

In my opinion, the game reminds me of many other games. Spiral knights in a way (indescribable), Fable for its music and atmosphere (the biome diversity reminds me of certain parts of that game), Minecraft done right (block building, farming, but with better combat, enemies, and a leveling/rpp system that is satisfying, yet not overburdening), and Terraria (boss fights [not a ton yet] and varying ways to attack enemies).

Overall, this is an extremely good early access game and I cannot wait for further updates to combat, to varying blocks, weapons, armor, and items, and to general functionality and added mechanics to make this entertaining buy an even deeper, even more fulfilling experience than it already is! Get this game and have a blast with your friends!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is my first review about a game,

The game is settled in nice little well made worlds that are loaded with alot of things to do.  I've played this game for a couple of hours now , and i think there's still room for improvement. I've played like 10 hours and i am already halfway, so the game goes very quick when i play it.  Let me sum up my pros en cons

pros: - nicely made worlds
- epic graphics
- plays smoothly
- loads of stuff to make and do
- balanced weaponery
cons: - gets boring after a while because most of the maps are of the same biom
- balanced shooting is a big point
-  More maps are needed
- maybe a little too much for what you get

I do recommend this game to buy, because the developpers team is constantly working on  improvement so i can't wait till the next update .  If you liked this review , please thumbs up :)
Greetings anton

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So far, so good. This game seems to tick the boxes and is almost a different take on Minecraft

+ It's got monsters to fight.
+ It has different classes of characters
+ you can be creative on a multitude of maps.
+ The visuals are great (considering I'm playing on my laptop).

but the things I find frustrating:

-block placing - seems a little slow (could be laptop performance)
-camera angle doesn't help building and can hinder fighting - Especially round trees!

I haven't gotten very far on the game so I can't say much for the bigger boss fights seen in the trailers but from what I've seen it could be a load of fun.
voteText: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

What I like about this game:
- Interesting game with quite a variety of portals to explore
- Difficulty increases slightly as you progress
- Pretty damn good graphics for a block game

Things that I do not exactly like or wish to feedback on:
- Storage should be fixed so that you can access both your backpack space as well as toolbar space instead of just the toolbar
- Warrior should be fixed so that it isn't almost trash at early game
- Should have spawn protection" so that we don't get instantly mauled when we spawn at some of the late game maps
- You should be able to split a stack of resources
- Grass texture with flowers is more disturbing than beautiful. Perfect situation where simple is beauty.
- Perhaps implement a way to increase backpack space via crafting or drops by bosses
- Create ways to disable spawning of mobs in spawned dungeons after a full clear so that it can be taken over as a fort
- Map is seriously tiny with limited biomes
- Some people have issues with accessing co-op mode

Overall:
It's a very good game however some people have issues with accessing co-op. Other than that
date: all is good. Got in on the 28th and it's pretty much all I've been playing after I got it. Note
recommended: this is the Early Access version so the bugs and flaws are somewhat expected."
voteText: true

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThe game tries to fuse Zelda, Cube World, and Minecraft all together with an art style the resembles Dungeon Defenders. How could that be a bad thing you ask? Well automatically by looking at the game you assume its a massive procedurally generated world similar to minecraft and such, but what it really is, is a small islands, like very small. Each level has an island and objectives to complete in order to finish a portal then once you finsh the portal you go to another really small island. This just repeats over, and over, and over. It makes this game seem much less like a Zelda/Minecraft mash up, and more like a 3D version of Clicker Heroes. Aesthetically its absolutely gorgeous, and it plays really well (Minus the lack of sprint which is extremely annoying), but for now the game is a repetitive bore. It is an early access game so that means its sure to improve, but for now just wait.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This Review will Change as the game gets Updated.

As of now the game has that whole Minecraft/Trove/Cubeworld feeling to it and it does the job good with pretty graphics and beautiful lighting. A few bugs here and there is to be expected from an Early Access game. The game lacks variety because the islands feel very repetative you got your basic snow, plains, swamp, desert, jungle, and thats it really...
Character customization isn't very deep, feels like you're making a MySim.

Pros:
- Good music
- Co-Op
- Pretty graphics
- Amazing lighting
- Boss fights
- First person and Thrid person view

Cons:
- Really frustrating camera lock in combat
- Limited inventory spaces (Including chests)
- No point in making a dungeon your own base because no possible way to stop enemy spawns
- Cannot reset key bindings
- No way to drop items from your inventory
- When you fast travel to an island in Co-Op all participants are forced to come with you
- Fighter class is rendered useless to floating enemies
- Very limited settings options (The Resolution and Fullscreen both of which do not work for me)
- Islands are pretty small, you could cross an island and reach the other side in under a minute

There is so much potential for this game and I can't wait for new content and improved gameplay!
Don't get me wrong this game is really fun its just that the cons outweigh the pros for now.

Okeh, this is only based on my opinion and a friend because we played together.
Do I recommend this?
Yea, because me and my friend are enjoying it because of the co-op mini rpg and minecraft-ish.
The game when playing alone is ok but frequently crashes if my friend is about to join.
I dont recommend to people who cant tolerate the frequent crashes.
Overall its an OK game for an early access game. I give it 6/10.

Below are some of my opinion.

-Details are good but each world sometimes has nothing to explore.
-Variety of weapons with attributes not that much.
-Bosses are sometimes predictable.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Awesome game, Well worth the money!! Over 50 hours logged!!

I don't normally write reviews on steam, but this game won my heart. If you like sandbox RPGs then this is definitely worth your $15. I didn't even realize it was early access for awhile, as this games graphics are polished and run fantastically on my ♥♥♥♥ Windows laptop.

Pros:
Minecraft with a focus on RPG traits like combat and gear customization.
-Great graphics (cartooney but self aware of it)
-Great Boss Battles
-Big ol' Dungeons
-Good variety of resources and maps
-GREAT CO-OP (Solo is very fun too, Co-op just takes it to another level)

Cons:
-Game becomes somewhat of a grind near end game (takes 20 titanium to smelt 1 bar)
-Crashed once or twice, usually with no repurcussions (although once I lost two full stacks of a much needed resource because I was smelting when it crashed) >:(
-Recycled monsters, just re-skinned in later levels.
-Warrior Class is garbage and useless, ended up using a bow for him anyways. (they should give him a shield or something)

In summary, I highly recommend this game (especially if your friends start it with you)
Many hours worth of exploration and although it did crash once or twice, this is to be expected from an Early Access game. I can't wait for updates and new levels.

Buy this game, idiot!

I'm not the first person to say this, and i sure won't be the last, but this is the love child of Minecraft, Terraria and Starbound, with a bit of Don't Starve DNA.

It's 3D, with a heavy enphasis on building, and it lets you explore dungeons at your own speed, like Minecraft.

The exploring consists of a lot of really small relams like Starbound.
And the combat consists of dodging to the sides, or kiting, while dishing out hits when available, like Don't Starve.


And like all 4 of them, it's a fantastic experience both singleplayer and multiplayer.

10/10 would play a videogame orgy again.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Played just under an hour of this game and really can't take much more. I saw the unveil trailer a good while ago and got rather excited about it, looked like it could be a fun game to play with some friends, playing as different classes and exploring, killing, and generally having good times. After a short play, I found I wouldn't be getting these things, as;

1. Combat is bad, really bad, melee isn't fun and the game takes control of the camera during combat, rather than giving you the OPTION to lock on, you either let the game control the camera or don't fight it's annoying. On top of this, range and magic are almost too easy considering the game will automatically target enemies for you, simply stand back, hold fire, and that's it, occassionally you have to dodge, or just step to the side a little.

2. Exploration is shoddy, areas are rather miniscule and uninteresting, and there's no incentive to build a house or settle on any island, because soon enough you're going to build a portal and be on your way. Part of sandbox games is generally the ability to create a house and settle, all you need here is a crafting station and that's it, build your equipment and go.

3. The movement of characters and camera are iffy, in order to be comfortable using the camera some tweaking is required, and the character seems a bit slow, not to mention that when trying to jump while beside a wall, characters just seem to slam right back down to the earth. Possibly more of a bug than anything, but come on, it's not like jumping mechanics are new, this kid of thing should be a big deal to get right!

These points are basically what makes me dislike the game, destroying the 'RPG Sandbox' nature of the game with poor combat, and poor exploration. I hope this game can become something greater as it progresses through Early Access, but for now, I can't say I like it very much.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Gameplay:
Portal Knights is an action game with click-heavy auto targeting combat that allows you to roll away from enemy attacks. When you kill enemies, there is a chance that the enemy will drop a portal shard - when you have enough portal shards, you can finish crafting a portal, placing the portal pieces in a Minecraft, block-placing fasion, you can teleport to the next small arena for harvesting portal shards. Eventually, there is a boss.

That's pretty much it. There is a whole system of materials, a workbench and furnace to craft more advanced items, and a whole host of decorative items from knight statues to different types of doors. Players barely ever need to touch any of it. Mechanically, combat feels clumsy. The movement and dodge roll on your character never seems to cooperate with the environment, like sometimes I'd end up on top of a bush or fall down a one block deep hole and get stuck for a second, but it didn't matter much since the enemies are nearly brain dead. The only ones you have to watch out for are the ones with quick lightning attacks in close quarters. Sometimes there are dungeons that go deep within the floating island that is each area, but the movement isn't tuned for indoors, so to fight enemies I just ate the damage and healed up when necessary.

I picked a wizard and used a magic wand to fight enemies. I think there are spells but after a handful of levels, and realizing the crafting/building portion of the game is completely unnecessary, I didn't acquire any before quitting. I actually think the minecraft part of the game hinders the game overall, as the block-based nature of the environments make them frustrating to navigate, and placing blocks is glitchy, as sometimes when building a dirt pole to ascend cliffs, I would occasionally place a dirt block directly above me, rather than below. The level generator did not produce anything inspiring during my play time.

Aesthetics
The game looks good for a block-based game. I appreciated the variety of enemies and how well-animated they were, but the enemies looked dumb standing there humping a wall or bumping up against me. My favorite was probably the turtle who would shell up and roll toward you, as video game turtles do. The foliage sometimes made the areas hard to navigate, and I'm just talking about the grass on top of dirt tiles, not to mention the various cotton shrubs, berry bushes, and agave plants that adorn the different grassy and desert environments. The whimsical look and tunes often reminded me of Fable.

Early-Access Verdict
No. I don't think it's Early Access that hurts this game. Portal Knights is one of the most polished Early Access games I've played, but the end goal of Keen seems to be adding MORE stuff, and I just don't think that's going to do the game any favors. The crafting is unnecessary, and without it you just have a barebones, tedious action game that wouldn't be any better with or without friends.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Not truly a sandbox game - mimics sandbox gameplay with a campagin-esque mode

I realize this is early access, but at this point the game is not close to ready yet; and the fact that devs feel that it is ready/near complete is scary. It's scary because it would be a shame to see a game with this much potential amount to nothing more than what Portal Knights currently is.

What Portal Knights currently is: a beautiful, but sadly very simple, linear storyline game with sandboxlike elements, but not a true sandbox game.

So yes, I obviously cannot recomend this as of now. Portal Knights has so much potential, but it could easily just be a moneyrun from the develeopers. Read my conclusion statement (bottom of the review) for a further explaination.


PROS:
Combat is done well in my opinion, but could be harder; rolling to dodge attacks, timing is key
Feels very polished in terms of gameplay mechanics
Clean; Portal Knights isn't glitchy or buggy, just very flat and lifeless
Looks amazing

CONS:
Game progression is extremely linear; does not feel like a sandbox game
World(s) are very small; only one biome per world
Abysmally small worlds take away all feelings of exploration

Random generation algorithms are bad; floating blocks, nothing for caves/islands/towers/castles
Barely any unique armor or weapons
Tier amror/weapon progression; copper->iron->gold is boring, not to mention gold armor makes no sense

Character creation needs more options
3 Simple classes doesnt feel like enough
Classes almost don't matter; the game allocates all your stat points for you; can't truly customize
Classes aren't balanced; playing as a warrior is a handicap

Worlds feel like a conglomerance of randomly generated blocks, there's no developed strctures and all in all it just feels empty



In depth:

Game Progression is too lienar - Randomly generated" worlds need to be a little more "random" in regards to their generation. It feels like I am playing a campaign for a storyline almost

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Absolute waste of time.  Me and my friend bought it thinking this could be a better looking minecraft/starbound/terraria, turns out it's as good as planet explorer(remember that game).

The world IS NOT RANDOMLY GENERATED.  IT IS THE SAME SEQUENCE OF MAP LOADERS OVER AND OVER AGAIN.  You must think, is it big?  Well, imagine you're living in an apartment, not the Will Smith big ♥♥♥ mansion, but something more like a middle class apartment in let's say new york.  You see the beautiful city below expanding into the sky, and you look back and see your tiny house yet you feel satisfied because it's your home.  That ♥♥♥♥ing city, is NOT what the game offers.  It offers you your little ♥♥♥♥♥♥ apartment, with what?  Hmm, lets see, oh, mining, yes, an excellent minecraft floating island that's as large as your tiny apartment room.

So, is there a variety of different terrains?  If you think going from the rain forests of Rio and then teleport to the deserts of Iraq, and then you end up in the rain forests of another national park, only to be teleported the deserts of Egypt, that's your variety right there.  They're blocks, there's green and yellow and grey, those are your color scheme for terrains.  So exploration wise, I would rather have some fun playing star bound (considering that game is pretty godamn huge)

Gameplay.  You attack, the monster doesn't stagger.  Monster attacks, pick a direction, WASD, and tap roll.  Repeat process.

Coop.  What is the point of even digging into that now... I did try, and it works perfectly fine, but it just doubles the time you get bored

Conclusion, me and my buddy were on a race to see who gets refund first.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

portal kinights review:

Hey guys, so I have played a few hours in the game and so far it is an awesome experience. Short of the combat being a bit tricky to get used to, the game has a lot to offer and it is addicting fun.

You get the feel of a minecraft style building and exploration mixed with a slowed down Trove style of combat. The upgrades available, new craftable items, the castles you discover and more, all add to the excitement you feel when you do something new.

I am definitely addicted to this game already. I hope that there is enough upgrade potential and replayability to keep things going. So far I am only level 9 in game but I can imagine how difficult things will be once you start to progress to higher levels.

Pros:
-Great artwork
-Easy to get the hang of
-Crafting is fun and easy but also requires you to kill enemies, travel to other levels, and more to potentially get what you need.
-Various areas and new things to discover
-Great RPG-like possibilities
-Leveling system
-Good variation of enemies so far

Cons (but not really cons. These are more like areas of improvement):
-Combat is a bit different to get used to
-Ranged attacks seem very limited
-No real way to aggro enemies other than to get closer
-I'm not completely sure but it doesnt seem that you can change keybings
