reviewText:
Early Access Review

Crafting too expensive. Once you upgrade your machines, you are left with nothing for you for your hours of gathering just to unlock recipes. Certain resources can grow up to 9 blocks wide making farming a pain when setting up farms. You can place down a seed even if it will never have room to actually grow which shouldn't be allowed IMHO.

Building portals is basically only a short load screen that will lead to another place to go and gather more junk later. I have seen portals that were burried in 20K+ blocks in terrain which is stop your progress if you refuse to mine that much blindly just to find it. No portal finding tools can even be crafted either to aid with that boring process.

Bosses are boring. You must always fight a boring boss to continue going to more islands.

Crafting lacks proper descriptions.

Grp functionality doesn't exist since you can't type to people in game, resources are not all renewable like ore, and their voice chat has no way to adjust it. So you are forced in grp play for co op to either play with all game sounds off or listening to Wendy fart non stop.

Classes? What classes? We had those? Oh, my bad! I didn't notice. There are currently 3 out of the 4 classes shown that you can actually play. Each going to level 30 but they don't truly have their own gear or combat. They can all share and wear the same gear and weapons. None of that is neeeded since only the crit warrior dps set at the highest quality level will actually do any dmg  making all other gearing sets useless. Craftable skills are used by all and all share a global cooldown so really you shouldn't have more than 1 on your tool bar. I suggest the heal so you can skip on potions forever. Mana isn't that much of an issue since you will only be using one weapon attack any way. Gear is not restricted by class.

Bulding blocks are too small which means you will need a lot more of them which equals more resources and more never ending farming. Islands too small. Digging is a problem as you currently fall out of the world way too much. Hard to dig around all that mess.

Game breaking bugs leaving you unable even move or craft or even allow you to close out the game without using task manager to do it.

No inventory space after making all mining tools and mining type items to aid you with mining and once you make your craftable abilities.

Lack of proper decriptions, on craftable skills or gear or even on chests to see their size.

NO WATER! You can only use that for making potions and get them from mob kills or some resources such a cactus but u don't need them for anything other than potions which can be skipped. Forget about making pools or fountains etc.

No way to make items in world you think are cool at this time since there is no recipe for it. You have to hope your world has enough items in it you can farm and explore via portals just to make 1 cool project like a castle with lots of gargoyles etc or knights. No creative mode.

Too expensive to craft. 4 copper ore = 1 copper bar. 10 iron ore = 1 iron bar. 20 gold ore = 1 gold bar. 40 titanium ore = 1 bar. WTF? Once your ore in your world is gone, it's gone forever. If you want to make another world for farming, that's on you. You will need to unlock all portals and get all shards for portal stones again. BORING!

Sub to follow game, skip for now. I play with others but we are about worn out from it. You gather, gather gather. Nothing more. Farm, but good luck crafting. The game does look really nice but that's about it. One of the most beautiful block games I have seen besides creativerse and windborne which is no longer in production. In the end there were many things I liked in this game but being early access as most steam games are now a days simply means, sure, nice game / has potential but needs a lot more ground work. I don't like feeling like ground work is missing in any game. I play with others however it feels like all we do is gather stuff non stop. It hasn't earned the tittle of my fav block game as of yet. Right now is a perfect time to critique the game as it is in it's infancy and still being worked on in hopes that it will blossom correctly later.

A kind reminder:
As with most early access games, devs add more stuff and kinda forget about the current stuff because they get so concerned with expanding and that's a shame. Also be aware that their dev size might be smaller as with most early access games which can lead so huge time spans between updates.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Portal knights a RPG sandbox voxel crafting game. The combat is leaning towards zeldaish aim target system which is not bad but it doesn't really work on this game. The camera is horrible! When you're really down in a dungeon the camera gets in the way and sometimes it leaves you caught up in the moment trying to fix the camera that you suddenly die! The crafting system is really feature friendly it shows you how to make items really nice so you don't have to use a wiki which is really great and there is the map system where it shows you what type of monster resources and other stuff that are in the area. Progression is really confusing after you complete the simple tutorial the game leaves you alone without no idication what to do next. The Building system is really easy like any other voxel game. The dungeons half of the time feels emtpy with little or no reward at all. The boss battles are amazing and unique which is great! Inventory wise it's really small and it is really fustrating trying to sift out the crap you don't really need. The game is missing alot of necessary things like camera improvements and inventory system needs to be pan out more and the combat is clunky at times.

So far i see great potential with this game and the Devs are really up front with the community taking suggestions and really up there interacting with the community as for the price of 15$ and 20% off first week is really freaking cheap for an early access game which is really good we need more like this!

Do i recommend it? As for the price and the content it shows you i would say yea get it but take note the combat system is really unique.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'm having a blast with this game. Its great for an early access. They delivered a fun, very playable product. I cannot wait to see what this evolves into.

The mining and crafting is pretty similar to Minecraft, and its voxel based, but thats where the similarities end. The RPG elements are clearly in their infancy and class selection doesnt mean a whole lot. I'm hoping to see it expanded.

The combat is pretty fun. As a Dark Souls junkie, I really appreciate the dodging and reaction based stuff. Its pretty easy though; as the ranger class, I've been able to take some pretty big hits and healing potions are easy to make. I'd love for a bit faster combat and harder enemies.

This is early access done right folks.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Portal Knights is a colorful, dainty, sandbox RPG.  I wouldn't rely too heavy on the sandbox bit however, it's different then your most average sandbox games.  Portal Knights offers 44 small islands to progress though.  Kill, loot, craft, and move on.  The game is quite fun for an alpha release but you're presented with a few bugs here and there.  For a game that's in it's alpha stage, I'm a little surprised it plays like a beta.  I would say knock down a few bugs and the game is ready for release.

If you're interested in crafting and level progression in a small sandbox, Portal Knights is the perfect game for you.  It's still early, there's a lot to do, add, and fix in Portal Knights.

Note: There's a reason for small worlds.  Remember, today it's 44 levels, tomorrow  could be 500.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game puts emphasis on sandbox construction; it's clear they want you to be building a base through the addition of many decoration blocks, farming and the crafting being focused around placed, upgradable workbenches. Conflictingly, at the same time the game forces you to jump worlds frequently due to the fact that each one is incredibly tiny and spawn only a very small fraction of the resources you need, so to progress craftwise you need to visit many worlds. In addition to this, the RPG character development is tied to jumping through progressively harder worlds. In multiplayer, everyone has to jump a world together, nobody can be left behind, which makes this the first game of its type to actually downgrade with multiplayer.

What does this game want you to do? You can't progress without building a base, but you can't build a base because you need to progress. Why include base mechanics if you are supposed to be constantly adventuring? Why is the crafting based around placed crafting benches??? You have to carry the benches around to craft on the move, but why have them like that in the first place? Why is there farming when you don't stay in one place?!

Basically the devs couldn't choose between two types of games, so they decided to do both and made no effort to allow them to compliment each other (unlike Terraria), so they end up destroying each other instead.

I suggest either;
A: increase each world size by about a factor of 100 and significantly reduce the prevelance/need of world jumping.
B: Remove all mechanics that are based on staying in one place; remove farming, forget decoration/furniture/building and allow you to craft everything without benches, instead focus on adventure, character progression and combat.

Don't tell players to constantly move around *and* stay in the same place at the same time, this is a paradox that makes the game unplayable.


EDIT: After writing this I found an article on Kotaku about Portal Knights, they are better than me at explaining this but they say basically the same thing here: http://www.kotaku.com.au/2016/02/steams-popular-portal-knights-channels-minecraft-and-zelda-comes-up-short/

- Block size seems too small to enjoy creation.

- Placing/removing blocks need much more work to achieve a smooth building experience.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

One of the few games worthy of being an early access title.  Portal Knights is a Sandboxesque rpg builder.  Well developed but there is room for more and indeed the devs do plan to add more.  The game has elements similar to Minecraft but it is its own game.  People considering this game should be aware that the world sizes for every portal are not these immense worlds and the game does not advertise them as such either.

The game itself actually runs exceptionally well for being an early access title.  All the game systems currently implemented work exceptionally well but a few need just a little bit of polish.  The devs explicitly stated they are shooting for the release candidate this year so this game should not suffer development hell that  many other Early Access titles on Steam are suffering from.

Another big positive from this game are the visuals.  This game is really quite gorgeous with its bright vibrant environments and colorful creatures.  If you ever played Dungeon Defenders it has a similar art pallete with that game.  The colors just pop out at you.  Graphical options are on the limited side but then again this game is not exactly designed to push boundaries in that department.

The main point of the game is to traverse across the different worlds farming resources and items to make your character stronger while at the same time unlocking all 44 locations throughout the world.  There is a full scale building element, and hidden blueprints to find in dungeons, or off bosses.  The game plays well in singleplayer but is even better when playing with your friends.

I would recommend this game for anyone that enjoys Minecraft type games but as I said before remember that each world size are not similar what you find in Minecraft.  Actually one excellent way to think of the game world is that each area could be considered a Biome in Minecraft because that is essentially what they are.  You have swampy worlds, lush forested worlds, fire worlds, snow worlds, and desert worlds.  At its current price which will only last for this week I would certainly recommend picking it up.

crafting tables
blocks

but you can also craft you own weapons and armour by collecting cotton, wheat, wood etc from the land and its not like the horrible graphics like minecraft, It has really nice graphs way better then minecraft, which makes this game alot more enjoyable, plus when you start your journey through this game, you can customize your character, like change your hair, eyes, colour etc, then you name your character and like an rpg style game go out and battle enemies depending on your class, you also get exp and perks when u level you which makes your character alot better thought the game.

You dont just stay in one area, you have alot of portals and new lands to explore and each one is different, with different enemies, materials, so you can build your house in each area or set it to one area and teleport back to your safe house.

It has an online mode so you and your friends can buddy up and you all can craft build basses or go out and attack major bosses or hordes of enemies.

If i was to rate this game id give it a 8/10
the online could be a little improved but not majorly but alround the game is fantastic and fun.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This review probably isn't fair because I haven't had a sufficient time to play the game. However, the reason for that IS a problem with the game. Lack of configurable controls make it unplayable. Not everybody uses WSAD. I can't play this game until that happens. Also, video is choppy even with a video card that well exceeds the minimum requirements. You'll want a really nice one to play this game.

Since I couldn't post this until I played at least five minutes, I suffered through it. I DO like the tutorial system. It gives enough info without being overly basic. But, how am I supposed to click on an enemy to evade them when clicking either attacks or changes camera. A few bugs to work out here, I suppose.

The camera system is weird, at best. I would probably do better at first person, but the lack of configurable controls make that hard to feel comfortable.

The recommend is a no, for now. I appreciate that the game is early access and they are still working on things. But the point I'm trying to make is this is a common problem with ALL early access games. Make configurable controls before you even launch on Steam. It should be one of the first things you do. Otherwise you are limiting who can even play your game!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Game looks good, plays well, is fairly entertaining. However when playing online with friends you all have to be in the same tiny zone, so if someone wants to farm or build and someone wants to mine resources or fight mobs you're kind of screwed. You all have to go to the same zone and be together at all times, certain resources and mobs are only in certain zones and your 'home' zone where you do most of your building (I would imagine) isn't where you're going to be most of the time when playing.

It lacks the freedom of other sandbox games that let you do what you want while someone does what they want.

Also; TLDR there's no ingame chat, I have no idea what's going on. I understand this is Early Access, but a multiplayer game with no chat is ridiculous.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Takes ideas from good games and does not (so far) manage to implement them in a way that make them enjoyable.
Liked The Legend of Zelda's Z targeting system? Well, here you're forced to use it, it would actually not be a bad thing if not for the fact that almost all of the mobility and the attack variations Z targeting is made for are missing. So basically, you've got the camera lock and the evade. The attack animations have higher priority than the evades, of course, otherwise it would actually feel responsive.
Liked the mining in Minecraft perhaps? Well, surely you don't like going underground then, so let's put all the ressources at ground level and nothing below.I only fought one boss before getting bored, but it was actually pretty well implemented (and very clearly based on The Legend of Zelda).
And I got bored really fast indeed. Unlocking the 'iron' tier, I saw that at least they were trying to diversify the otherwise ridiculously basic classes, but since the battle system is so simplistic I really didn't care much, and then I saw the grind required for those armors (bear in mind this is the third tier). Grind is fine if the game has enough depth to make it fun (see: Warframe) and Portal Knights... does not, in any way.

The general presentation (UI and graphisms) is excellent. For some reason the configuration menu's resolution option will let you select resolutions the game won't actually use, but whatever. The Dr. Who loading screen is nice too. Performance is not an issue either.

The only bug I noticed in 4 hours of gameplay is a monster's shadow in the void. Which is to say, there's no problem there.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So, I have played verry little of this game so far. However there are some basic things that need to be addressed before I can recommend this game.

Id like to start by saying this game has potential, and has some fun ideas, however they don't seem very fleshed out at this point. So onto my problems with the game, first of all. The controls and movement are.. off puting. This may be personal to me and few others, however I think the movement and animations feel a little slow and clunky. It seems like the animations are set as they are intended, which worries me because the game just doesn't feel right in that regard.

Secondly, if you're a knight at least. The combat is basically minecraft combat.. which is awful. It's walk up to the enemy and click the attack key until it dies. Which is boring. This game looked like a combat oriented RPG style sandbox building game, but with combat like this, the combat is something that you feel like you'd rather avoid, for how boring and frustrating it can be.

Then, there is the world. People seem to be touching on this quite a lot, and I agree to an extent. The world is verry small and your objective is to find the portal and move on to the next area. In doing this you'll want to craft new equipment to help you survive. This is entertaining for what it is, but what I'd rather see is a large, endless, randomly generated world, or at least a game mode where this exists. Reason being: It gives more incentive for exploration and creation. Currently there is no real point. Find materials to upgrade, kill monsters to build up the portal, then move on.

That's the jist of what I have to say about this game so far here. I think they could do very well, but in its current state it's isn't something I'd recommened. I'd wait for release, or at least wait until it's further along on it's development. However some of the issues I've stated may be core gameplay descisions, that were created on purpose. Maybe not for this reaction.. but that might mean they may never be changed.

Keep an eye on it, but keep your distance for the time being.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Can't in good conscious rate this game up yet in it's early access stage. Game lacks a purpose for now. Maps are really small (think small floating islands you can fully explore in about 2 minutes). With each new island you go too, via portals, the only purpose was to explore the surroundings (above and below), find a few insignificant treasures while you look for portal to the next island. Played for about 2hrs and got bored after reaching the 7th island as it was just a rince and repeat of the previous island each time with different lighting and blocks. Not very exciting.

Albeit, the game does look promising if they include some incentives to keep the player interested to keep playing.

Pros:
Character creation options (limited but fun/amusing).
Great color schemes and graphics.
Variety of monsters I've seen in the short period of play time was ok.
Despite what others say, the crafting system isn't bad.
Short tutorial at the begining (via 3 quests - and these are the only quests)

Cons:
No plot.
No Quests (descriptioin says 'craft your adventure', but there isn't any adventure in sight. Just running around looking for a portal to the next island).
Not a sandbox as claimed.
Combat is similar to minecraft (I only played the Ranger - Stand still, click mouse and hold to shoot. Dodge occasionally)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It took 12 hours of uncertainty. Going in blind. Seeing zero content on the game. I can NOT recommend this game in its current state.

tl;dr - No. Crafting is awful. The game is a grind. And building is almost entirely pointless other than building your way up a cliff. And loot sucks.

I honestly don't feel like typing the long version. I was uncertain up till 10 hours of playing and realized it just wasn't fun grinding for ore that scalled with the late game, hundreds of gold ore and coal and such for only a few ingots. An awful crafting menu that shows every single stations items of crafting regardless what station you opened... There was no point in building a house since they give you one on the first stage, and storage is near impossible to manage. And item stack sizes (other than blocks) are just so low you end up with many MANY stacks of things you don't want (i just throw them away). And ugh.

You know, it really was fun for awhile. I just can't be bothered anymore haha.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I was pretty excited about this game. I expected a Legend of Zelda/Minecraft kind of experience, but unfortunately got a cheap off-brand lego children's game. The music/ atmosphere is nostalgic enough, but the actual combat gameplay is designed for 6 year old's. In order to attack something you automatically lock on. From there you just hold the attack button and dodge. No skill required, certainly no challenge involved. The leveling system is incredibly simple. Not in a good  way. There is no room for decision making when leveling your character and the weapon and armor progression is just as linear. The building mechanics of the game are pretty decent, from what I could tell.

Conclusion: If you enjoy a challenge, don't bother. It was a good try, just poorly executed.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Don't be fooled by the amount of hours I have put in this game. I have played offline as well.

My experience with Portal Knights went from : Wow! Cool, this is new want to explore more!

to REQUIRE MORE MINERALS.

Seriously the only thing that drove me was the fact that I lacked minerals and needed more. Worlds are very small, dungeons can go really deep underground but offer VERY LITTLE in return. Basically couple of ores some potions, experience and most importantly NO LOOT. Yep, no armors or weapons. That for me is a deal breaker. Lackluster exploring.

When you do grind for hours just to get the sword you like it truns out to be utter crap. Why? Well I played as warrior I had miserable 5% more STR than other classes but still my gold sword was outclassed by iron crossbow... Even though sword had way more Damage ( at least on paper ). However when I attacked enemy I did 75 dmg while my crossbow did 100-150... So whats the point of playing a warrior? ALSO armors are a joke!

Seriously Marskman armor has 200 defense THE SAME AMOUNT of defense that Gold Viking Vest or any gold plate armor... On top of that a lot of archer armors have Dodge skill which makes it totally unfair . There has to be some balancing done otherwise there is no point on playing as warrior.

Some daggers have sick stats that feel overpowered and yet rare swords or hammers are underpowered.

OK so let's sum it up : Small crap worlds, lack luster exploring, NEEDLESS grinding and when you find a portal to a new world usually its the same CRAPPY WORLD! Found icy world with marble stone and coal? Goes through gate... same things marble and coal except layout is a bit different. WTF?! Dissapointing.

GAMEPLAY.

Barebones. I was very frustrated with DAMN auto lock on camera! Seriously kill it already. No blocks, no parries, just dodging that doesnt always work ( if you are too early to dodge or dodge the last second you will get hit ). So even though I player as warrior I ended up using bows because of higher damage and kiting possibility. Mages are crap because of mana constraints and to get skills you really need to upgrade magic station.

Leveling up feels unrewarding and you have little to none options available on how to distribute stats.

Honestly this game feels like a wasted potential. I hope they will improve the combat, character customisation and building/placing blocks is a bit frustrating. You can't really place blocks on empty space. Because of this I have lost a lot of resources...

I cant recommend this game just yet, Unless you are a masochist or just like casual games like this.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I agree with all the points in other negative reviews.  There isn't much game here.  The islands are very small and there isn't much to explore.  The worlds are boring and more of the same.

This game is a grind with nothing to look forward to except some more generic gear to get you to the next portal.

I also tried playing warrior and the combat is impossibly hard.  The auto-target system does not work well.  You can not jump in combat and tab target switching rarely works.  If you want easy mode use a ranged weapon and you will have no problems.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nIf I'd need to describe Portal Knights in few words, I would say casual Minecraft-like action"
date: "casual" being the main word here.This review describes v0.3.0
recommended: Early Access. If you're looking at the "not recommend" flag: I'm not saying the game's horrible
hoursPlayed: mind you. It's more... "not for everyone". For me it gets boring rather quick. If I would be given a 1 to 5 scale
voteText:
I'd rate it 3. Interested in details? I got them for you.

Pros:
+ Coherent cartoonish graphic style
Something PK excels at
helpfulPercent: graphic style is kept at professional level and is arguably the best among all sandboxes. Diversity of blocks (and props) is something the game improved in recently and I think it won't be the last time devs do it.\n+ Overall stability\nSomething you don't see often in Early Access games
votesHelpful: PK is quite stable. It rarely crashes and even more rarely throws bugs your way.\n+ Easy to grasp
votesTotal: forgiving gameplay\nWhile some can say it's a drawback
votesFunny: this game doesn't make you shake in horror being afraid to lose everything you've got so far. Resurrection is instant and causes no penalties (aside from the fact you're always resurrecting in the same place). You don't drop any items upon death.\n+ Quick resource regeneration
commentsCount: no resource destruction\nWhile all the blocks can be mined
column16: most can be acquired without mining through farming mobs
column17: the exception being simple dirt (and any world mostly consists of it so there are lots). Trees and crops grow (relatively) fast. As I've said
column18:
it's a casual game. Bombs and exploding monsters don't destroy blocks but "mine" them (you can pick them up later). Few ways to destroy blocks completely include dropping them into the Abyss surrounding each island or waiting for the mined blocks to despawn.

Cons:
- No goal in the game
While "lack of a goal" may sound strange for a sandbox
column19: there is actually not much you can do here. Monsters and "bosses" aren't much of a challenge. Currently the basic principle of gameplay can be described as "beat mobs
column21: jump into hext island". Repeat. There are no NPCs
column22: little lore and no story. There are no quests
column23: no pets to tame or rare things to collect. The latest updates brought random events though
column24: so there finally is something you can look for.\n- Lacking and mandatory crafting\n"Lacking" doesn't mean it's downright bad. But most props and gear can be built straight away if you have the right crafting stations and resources
column25: few recipes dropping from monsters (and even these can be skipped). You'll skip most early weapons and armors as you get new resources much faster than use them (especially copper).\nResource requirements for crafting are unbalanced
column26: especially late-game. While you can easily craft your first forge
column27: gathering high-tier stone/metal for the upgrades quickly turns into a digfest (or grindfest). Conversion rates for late game metals (ore to bars) is ridiculous (was even more so before the devs halved it
column28: and it's still high).\nEarly recipes are fine
column29: with the exception of a torch which requires cotton (growing and dropping only in first biomes) and 3 Wood (which is what roughly one tree drops). If you're going for torches (and you'll need lots of them for exploration) it's much easier to get to the desert island
column30: wait for the night and kill Fire Knights - every knight drops one.\nLast
column32: crafting is mandatory and is the only way of obtaining better equipment. Monsters
column34: and treasure boxes don't drop armor
column35: weapons or props and drop few recipes.\n- "Classes" have little difference\nAll stats are raised during level-up simultaneously. Skill tree doesn't give many cool things
column36: if any. Every class has spells but weapons are generally more efficient
column37: so a mage doesn't usually do magic. Armor and weapons aren't bound to a class (which is good) and are of little usefullness beyond protection/damage and HP/MP increase (which is bad). Thus
column38: little to no specialization. Playing every class is basically the same.\n- No treasure hunting\n"Treasure" boxes

column41: crafting ingredients and healing hearts (and rarely
column42: recipes). All gear and most props are crafted. The game has no traders and no currency so crawling dungeons has sense only in search of portals.\n- Fragmented game world
column43: static biomes\nThere is actually no "game world"
column44: just small islands flying in the Abyss and connected by portals. Big enough to explore
column45: small enough to not get tired of distances.\nThe size
column47: has its drawbacks. Abyss means no water or lava (or any other liquid whatsoever).\n"Biomes" are bound to islands
column48: don't depend on soil or any other factors and are mostly decorative. Monsters and crops are also bound to islands so you can't bring your favourite mobs/crops to the world you like.\n- Static spawn system\nSpawn system is extremely predictable. Mid-game you'll know how many mosters are there in a room before entering it. There is no way to prevent spawning. In most sandbox games light sources or player-placed artificial blocks prevent monster spawning. In PK there is no such (or any other) system. reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you want to play a better version of this game for free, go look up Sky Saga.

Both games are in alpha, but Sky Saga's key features work way better than this game's.

Problems with this game (and yes, I know it's early access):
-The islands are too small. Considering this is a key feature, there's little hope this will change over the development period. There are so many islands, why care about a single one of them? They function all the same and do not influence each other at all. Even if they add more biomes and such, they all feel pointless. It doesn't help that there is no exploration, as you can often see the exit for an island from its entrance.

-The combat is very dull. They might change some of this later, but as of now, the Zelda-style camera is the only interesting thing. Your attacks are all the same, there's no variety or jump attacks or anything like you might find in a Zelda game. You just target an enemy and hold down the attack button. Occasionally you backpedal. That's it.

-Classes have no meaning. Any class can equip any weapon, so why have classes? There are no special attacks, and in the RPG progression, you can't even choose what skills to learn. It's all linear. Not to mention that attacking with a bow and attacking with a wand are exactly the same. There's no interesting spells or anything.

-No quests. I hope you like the first three tutorial quests because those are the only ones you'll find. This game touts its lack of direction as open ended gameplay" and "player driven questing." When your only options of interacting with the game are holding down the attack button on enemies and building a crafting table you'll never use again once you leave whatever tiny island you are currently on
date: there isn't much agency or ability for players to "create their own stories."\n\n-Repetitive. Everything is repetitve. Even with different biomes and different enemies
recommended:
its all just
1) Enter new island
2) Kill enemies for portal shards
3) Craft portal blocks
4) Stick blocks in portal
5) Rinse and repeat

Again
hoursPlayed: if you want a game with a lot of variety
voteText: interesting combat
helpfulPercent: large islands with lots to explore
votesHelpful: home islands you can return to
votesTotal: community quests
votesFunny: a huge healthy community of clever builders and explorers
commentsCount: and all of that for free
